Absolute attacks and severity have increased; a simple regression vs. market cap yields R²=0.45. Normalizing by Coinbase MAUs and market cap shows per-user/per-dollar risk fell since 2015, though recent per-user upticks align with 2021 levels. Western Europe and APAC show the largest increases. Thread includes interactive visualizations, code link, and practical personal-security recommendations.","key_points":[{"header":"Dataset and finding","bullets":["Analysis uses Jameson Lopp's curated wrench-attacks database of reported violent crypto thefts.","Absolute number of attacks rose substantially from 2017 onward, peaking sharply in 2024–2025.","Severity shifted toward more Serious/Severe incidents; Fatal incidents appear from 2017 onward."]},{"header":"Market-cap correlation","bullets":["Simple regression of violence vs. total crypto market cap gives R² ≈ 0.45 (market cap explains ~45% of variance).","Higher market value correlates with more attacks in absolute terms, per the white-line vs bars visualization."]},{"header":"Normalization and alternative view","bullets":["Normalized metrics: attacks per Coinbase MAU and attacks per $B market cap show much higher rates in 2015 and 2018.","Per-user risk fell as user base grew (Coinbase MAUs from ~2M to ~120M), though there's a recent moderate uptick near 2021 levels."]},{"header":"Geography & action","bullets":["Western Europe and APAC show the largest increases in violence; North America remains relatively safer in this dataset.","Practical advice: avoid signaling wealth, use PO boxes/hot wallets, delete personal data, consider security guards if high-risk."]}],"projects":[{"project_id":23808,"project_name":"Coinbase"}],"images":[{"url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1767534403/veldt/efsdkp2tkmyqojmrsopk.jpg","title":"Normalized Crypto Physical Attack Rates (2014-2025)","description":"A line chart titled 'Normalized Attack Rates Over Time' that compares two metrics from 2014 to 2025: 'Attacks per million Coinbase MAUs' (blue line) and 'Attacks per $B market cap' (green line). The chart shows a significant peak for both metrics in 2015, with attacks per million users reaching approximately 2.5 and attacks per $B market cap reaching 1.0. Following 2015, both rates dropped sharply. The attacks per $B market cap have remained near zero since 2017, indicating that attacks are not scaling linearly with market valuation. The attacks per million Coinbase users stabilized between 0.3 and 0.6 from 2019 to 2024, with a slight upward trend projected for 2025. This data suggests that while absolute numbers of attacks might be increasing, the relative risk per user and per dollar of market value has significantly decreased since the early years of the crypto industry."},{"url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1767534282/veldt/bjnagniloxgxpyupxz7t.jpg","title":"Severity Breakdown of Physical Crypto Attacks 2014-2025","description":"A data dashboard visualizing the severity of physical attacks on cryptocurrency users, categorized into five levels. The top section provides a summary of 269 total incidents: Minor (23 incidents, 9%), Moderate (39 incidents, 14%), Serious (137 incidents, 51%), Severe (57 incidents, 21%), and Fatal (13 incidents, 5%). Definitions for each level are provided, ranging from 'Theft without confrontation' for Minor to 'Victim was killed' for Fatal. The bottom section features a stacked bar chart showing the percentage breakdown of these severity levels by year from 2014 to 2025. The data reveals a shift in attack composition: 2014 was 100% 'Minor' attacks, whereas from 2018 onwards, 'Serious' (orange) and 'Severe' (red) attacks dominate the distribution. 'Serious' attacks, involving armed robbery or home invasion, consistently represent the largest portion of incidents in the latter half of the decade. 'Fatal' incidents (purple) are visible in the breakdown for most years starting from 2017."}]},{"development_id":182178,"development_date":"2026-01-02T00:00:00+00:00","text":"Paladin announced it is shutting down on 2026-01-02, saying upcoming MCP (expected 2027) will make out-of-protocol block-building and bundle mechanisms obsolete.","type":"organization_and_operations","subtype":"project_shutdown","projects":[{"thumbnail":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1756496067/veldt/bs4poqqijydj8fgjjrdd.jpg","project_id":31420,"project_name":"Paladin"}]},{"development_id":174176,"development_date":"2025-12-22T00:00:00+00:00","text":"OpenMid Facilitator deployed to Base mainnet on 2025-12-22, enabling ERC-8004 agent registration inside the x402 payment flow and sponsored facilitation so developers can run the flow for free.","type":"launch","subtype":"project_launch","projects":[{"thumbnail":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1764099226/veldt/quxcyfmozevjpeykogte.jpg","project_id":42402,"project_name":"OpenMid"}]},{"post_id":325765,"post_link":"https://x.com/artemis/status/2007111541695324401","published_date":"2026-01-02T15:27:36+00:00","title":"2025 DEX Spot Volume Review","source_name":"artemis","summary":"Artemis' 2025 year-in-review: total DEX spot volume rose by roughly $2.1T to ~$4.2T. The y-axis represents total volume in USD, ranging from $0 to $5T. The chart shows a massive surge in total volume in the final year, reaching approximately $4.2T. Claims: theoretical finality of 100–150ms (from 12.8s) and simulated block propagation as low as 18ms. Initial activation expected early–mid 2026.","key_points":[{"header":"Alpenglow overview","bullets":["Alpenglow replaces Tower BFT and PoH to target sub-second finality for Solana.","Votor replaces incremental rounds with offchain vote aggregation, finalizing in one or two confirmation rounds.","Fast finalization: ≥80% stake approval in first round finalizes immediately.","Slow finalization: first-round 60–80% needs second round >60% to finalize; both paths run concurrently.","Rotor restructures block propagation with stake-weighted relay paths; simulation shows propagation as low as 18ms."]},{"header":"Performance & timeline","bullets":["Theoretical finality reduced to ~100–150 ms (≈100x faster than 12.8s baseline).","Rotor prioritizes high-stake, high-bandwidth validators as relays for efficient propagation.","Upgrade rollout expected gradually with initial activation anticipated early to mid 2026.","Tweet includes a technical diagram mapping leader, relay, notarization, and final vote timing."]}],"projects":[{"project_id":11943,"project_name":"Solana"}],"images":[{"url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1767383169/veldt/y8imtdc87xd8g0qt7fsx.jpg","title":"Alpenglow Block Life Cycle Diagram","description":"A technical diagram illustrating the 'Full Common Case Life Cycle of a Block in Alpenglow,' a proposed consensus overhaul for the Solana blockchain. The diagram uses a horizontal timeline format with four distinct tracks: 'Leader sends' (purple arrow), 'Relays send' (green arrow), 'Notar. votes' (pink arrows), and 'Final. votes' (blue arrow). The process begins with the leader and relays sending data. The first phase of notarization votes leads to the 'Notarization' milestone. A subsequent, shorter phase of notarization votes leads to 'Fast-finalization.' Concurrently, a longer 'Final. votes' process culminates in the 'Slow-finalization' milestone. This visualization demonstrates the parallel nature of block propagation and the tiered finality system (Fast vs. Slow) introduced by the Alpenglow architecture, which utilizes components like Votor for vote aggregation and Rotor for relay propagation."}]},{"post_id":327971,"post_link":"https://x.com/0xKofi/status/2007558625670111657","published_date":"2026-01-03T21:04:09+00:00","title":"EIP-7702 2025 usage trends","source_name":"0xKofi","summary":"Kofi (BundleBear) summarizes EIP-7702 adoption in 2025: 6.6M wallets currently hold active 7702 authorizations (40% tied to hacker contracts). latency constrains open-chain logic.","FHE is feasible in demos but impractical for general on-chain use in 2026.","TEEs provide high performance but retain hardware trust and supply-chain risks."]},{"header":"Institutional Use Cases","bullets":["Tokenized assets and confidential payments enable private settlements with selective disclosure.","Custodians use MPC and shielded contracts to reconcile privacy with auditability.","Trade finance and invoicing are early, high-fit applications for private ledgers."]},{"header":"Risks and Governance","bullets":["Zcash developer exodus exposed governance, funding, and talent concentration risks.","Privacy-as-a-moat can create lock-in but may hinder cross-chain interoperability.","Regulators accept privacy paired with oversight; opaque systems risk deplatforming."]}],"projects":[{"project_id":508,"project_name":"ALEO"},{"project_id":8605,"project_name":"Monero"},{"project_id":12388,"project_name":"Starknet"},{"project_id":13279,"project_name":"Tornado Cash"},{"project_id":14894,"project_name":"Zcash"},{"project_id":29356,"project_name":"Paxos"},{"project_id":39155,"project_name":"Canton Network"}],"images":[{"url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1767895886/veldt/xqxgbxpxdvlimoy1x8ke.jpg","title":"Comparison of Privacy Enhancing Technologies: MPC vs TEE vs FHE","description":"A comparison table titled 'PETs TODAY' evaluating three Privacy Enhancing Technologies (PETs): Multi-Party Computation (MPC), Trusted Execution Environments (TEE), and Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE). \n\nFor MPC, the pros include shared state, sharded secrets, and permissionless delegated compute; the cons are trust assumptions across a non-colluding set of nodes, slowness for multi-operations, and latency/low I/O due to communication delays with many nodes. \n\nFor TEE, the pros include being highly performant, highly expressive, having a mature developer experience (DevEx), multiple viable types, and the ability to run in cloud/data centers with abstraction; the cons are trust assumptions across an opaque hardware supply chain and infrastructure operators, and being memory bound. \n\nFor FHE, the pros include being collusion resistant (especially without decryption) and having schemes that can potentially be made post-quantum secure; the cons are being slow for single operations, computationally expensive, volatile due to noise, requiring MPC trust for decryption via a network key, and having many moving parts (schemes, parameters, hardware) for developers."}]},{"post_id":319355,"post_link":"https://x.com/EpochAIResearch/status/2005686960099348539","published_date":"2025-12-29T17:06:49+00:00","title":"Decentralized AI training: 600,000x growth","source_name":"EpochAIResearch","summary":"Epoch AI presents data and techniques showing decentralized training runs grew ~600,000x since 2021 (implied 20x/year trend). After filtering smart-contract noise, findings: P2P transactions are 67% of counts but only 24% of volume; business-related transfers (B2B + Internal B) are <8% of transactions yet >33% of volume. Weekday-dominant cadence, high concentration (top 1,000 senders ≈84% volume), and larger per-transaction values for businesses indicate stablecoins are emerging as a settlement layer for corporate payments, treasury routing, cross-border payouts and supplier payments. Analysis uses Artemis EOA labeling; results exclude proprietary payments partner data.","key_points":[{"header":"Scope & Method","bullets":["Study covers all USDC and USDT transfers on Ethereum from Aug 2024–Aug 2025, focusing on EOA→EOA transfers as payments.","Artemis labeling classifies wallets (individual vs institution) and excludes smart-contract interactions, mints/burns, and bridge events.","Filtering removes automated DeFi/small-value bot activity to estimate economically meaningful payment flows."]},{"header":"Key Quantitative Findings","bullets":["P2P = 67% of EOA→EOA transactions but only ~24% of volume; many P2P are low-value, likely bots or automated.","Business-related transfers (B2B + Internal B) <8% of transactions yet contribute >33% of total volume.","Top 1,000 sender wallets account for ~84% of volume, showing heavy institutional concentration."]},{"header":"Behavioral Patterns","bullets":["Weekday-heavy activity with sharp weekend drops, matching corporate payment cycles rather than retail trading.","Transaction-value CDFs show business categories have much higher values than P2P; very small transfers (<$0.1) flagged as suspicious.","Volume increased materially from Aug 2024 to Aug 2025, with rising weekly adoption across categories."]},{"header":"Implications","bullets":["Stablecoins function increasingly as business settlement infrastructure for treasury routing, supplier payouts, and cross-border settlement.","Programmability and global interoperability make stablecoins attractive for institutional liquidity management.","Findings inform regulators, payments providers, and financial institutions assessing digital settlement futures."]}],"projects":[{"project_id":4694,"project_name":"Ethereum"},{"project_id":12930,"project_name":"Tether"},{"project_id":13687,"project_name":"USDC"},{"project_id":23086,"project_name":"Fireblocks"},{"project_id":23808,"project_name":"Coinbase"}],"images":[]},{"post_id":341158,"post_link":"https://ournetwork.xyz/p/on-384-yield","published_date":"2026-01-09T23:59:59+00:00","title":"Yield: Sector Update — Pendle & Merkl","source_name":"OurNetwork","source_author":"OurNetwork","summary":"Stablecoin benchmark yields fell to ~3.8%. It coordinates five learning stores: User Profile for structured data, User Memory for unstructured observations, Session Context for task continuity, Entity Memory for facts and relationships, and Learned Knowledge for collective intelligence. The system supports various learning modes (ALWAYS, AGENTIC, PROPOSE) and custom schemas, enabling personalized and intelligent agent behavior. The cookbook provides practical examples and setup instructions for deploying agents with PostgreSQL and OpenAI models, demonstrating incremental profile building, task planning, and knowledge transfer across sessions. Key point: Agno's Learning Machine unifies AI agent learning.","key_points":[{"header":"Unified Learning System for AI Agents","bullets":["Agno's Learning Machine integrates five core learning stores: User Profile, User Memory, Session Context, Entity Memory, and Learned Knowledge.","Each store handles distinct knowledge types, from structured user preferences to collective insights, enabling comprehensive agent learning.","The system supports various learning modes (ALWAYS, AGENTIC, PROPOSE) and custom schemas for flexible agent development."]},{"header":"Key Learning Stores and Their Functions","bullets":["User Profile captures structured user data for personalization, while User Memory stores unstructured observations for contextual understanding.","Session Context tracks conversation state, goals, plans, and progress for task continuity.","Entity Memory builds a knowledge graph of external entities, and Learned Knowledge stores reusable insights via a vector database for semantic search."]},{"header":"Practical Implementation and Customization","bullets":["The cookbook provides practical examples for setting up and deploying learning agents with PostgreSQL and OpenAI/Claude models.","It demonstrates incremental profile building, task planning, knowledge transfer, and the creation of custom, database-backed learning stores.","The system is designed for extensibility, allowing developers to define custom schemas and integrate bespoke learning mechanisms."]}],"projects":[{"project_id":37441,"project_name":"Agno"}],"images":[]},{"post_id":308190,"post_link":"https://x.com/artemis/status/2003126040064049402","published_date":"2025-12-22T15:30:38+00:00","title":"Stablecoin Wrapped 2025 — Key Metrics","source_name":"artemis","summary":"Artemis & TokenizedPod present \"Stablecoin Wrapped 2025\" with headline metrics: USDT added $48.2B in 2025 (more than next five issuers combined); Claude Code (Opus 4.5) can autonomously develop, test, and deploy software for hours, demonstrated by a 1h14m run that created a working prompt-store site. Key enablers: long-run compaction, Skills (reusable instruction+tool bundles), subagents, and the Model Context Protocol (MCP). METR shows exponential increases in task-duration capability. Desktop and CLI access exist (desktop $20/mo). Major implications for developers, knowledge workers, and productization of AI-generated work — but serious security and data-risk tradeoffs.","key_points":[{"header":"Key Result","bullets":["Claude Code (Opus 4.5) executed a 1h14m autonomous workflow producing a deployed website.","Produced hundreds of code files, a deploy script, and a functioning sales page for prompt packs.","Autonomy extended beyond coding to browser-based user testing and iterative fixes."]},{"header":"Core Techniques","bullets":["Compaction: conversation summaries to preserve progress when context windows fill.","Skills: self-selected instruction/tool bundles that load context and capabilities on demand.","Subagents: specialized lightweight models for parallelized, context-isolated tasks."]},{"header":"Product Access","bullets":["Two main interfaces: Command-line (full features) and Claude Desktop (easier, limited features).","Desktop requires subscription (~$20/month) and folder access; CLI exposes more slash commands.","Slash commands enable /agents, /skills and other agent-management actions."]},{"header":"Use Cases & Workflows","bullets":["Rapid prototyping: build, test, and deploy small web products with minimal human coding.","Research pipelines: subagents and MCPs let AIs pull domain content (papers, APIs).","Design iteration: AIs can generate, playtest, and refine creative simulations or games."]},{"header":"Risks and Implications","bullets":["Security: local file access and code execution can delete or expose sensitive data.","Economic: programming roles will be refactored toward orchestration and AI-harness skills.","Ethical: generated marketing claims, fake reviews, and liability for automated deployments."]}],"projects":[{"project_id":24275,"project_name":"Codex"},{"project_id":24573,"project_name":"Google"}],"images":[{"url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1767847254/veldt/khfynlxdnrmcpv7ijzdg.jpg","title":"LLM Software Engineering Task Duration Capability Over Time","description":"A scatter plot and trend line chart from METR showing the exponential increase in the time-horizon of software engineering tasks that different LLMs can complete with a 50% success rate. The x-axis tracks LLM release dates from 2020 to 2025, and the y-axis measures human task duration in hours, ranging from 0 to 5 hours. Early models like GPT-2, GPT-3, and GPT-3.5 (2020-2022) show near-zero capability. GPT-4 (2023) marks the beginning of a sharp upward trend. Projected and recent models for 2025 show significant gains: o4-mini (~1 hour), GPT-5 (~1.75 hours), GPT-5.1-Codex-Max (~2.75 hours), and Claude Opus 4.5 (~4.75 hours). Specific task benchmarks are mapped to the y-axis: training a classifier (~45 min), fixing bugs in small Python libraries (~1 hour), exploiting a buffer overflow in libiec61850 (~2.25 hours), and training an adversarially robust image model (~4 hours). The dashed trend line indicates an accelerating capability for AI to handle increasingly complex and time-consuming autonomous engineering tasks."},{"url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1767847434/veldt/lgxldumb001bs7y3lzor.jpg","title":"Claude Code Autonomous Startup Development Demo","description":"A composite screenshot demonstrating the capabilities of Claude Code (v2.0.76) in autonomously developing a software-based startup. The process begins with a user prompt requesting a startup idea that generates $1000/month with zero ongoing effort. The AI agent, powered by Opus 4.5, performs an 'Honest Reality Check' and then proposes a 'Digital Product + Landing Page' system for a Premium AI Prompt Library. The image highlights that Claude Code ran independently for 1 hour and 14 minutes to build the project. The final output includes a terminal message confirming the completion of 'Project Vault' and a screenshot of the resulting website titled 'AI Prompts That Actually Work'. The generated site includes 500 AI prompts across 10 categories such as Business, Marketing, and Coding, with integrated payment options via Gumroad or Lemon Squeezy and a one-command deployment script."}]},{"post_id":315034,"post_link":"https://x.com/VitalikButerin/status/2004575793750355971","published_date":"2025-12-26T15:31:27+00:00","title":"Vitalik on pluralism, DSA, and platform policy","source_name":"VitalikButerin","summary":"Vitalik criticizes a \"no space\" approach to content moderation, calling it totalitarian and likely to produce technocratic authoritarianism. He opposes banning individual anonymity while supporting measures that reduce amplification of harmful content.","key_points":[{"header":"Critique of absolutist moderation","bullets":["Calling the \"no space\" refrain totalitarian and anti-pluralistic, especially for subjective, controversial categories.","Argues maximalist removal goals create conflict and empower technocratic enforcement machinery."]},{"header":"Policy prescriptions","bullets":["Favor a Pirate Party style: user empowerment over top-down bans and expert-driven shifting agendas.","Require algorithmic transparency: publish algorithms with a 1–2 year delay and use zk-proofs to attest to runtime fidelity."]},{"header":"Practical tradeoffs","bullets":["Support incentives for platforms to reduce harmful amplification rather than erecting rigid walls.","Prefer privacy-preserving, macro-scale community analytics to de-anonymization; USB-C analogy used to argue for interoperability."]}],"projects":[],"images":[]},{"post_id":314167,"post_link":"https://x.com/haydenzadams/status/2004265701083918475","published_date":"2025-12-25T18:59:15+00:00","title":"Unification vote passes — 100M UNI burn & fee switch","source_name":"haydenzadams","summary":"Unification governance vote succeeded: 125,342,017 YES vs 742 NO. Tokenized stocks exploded (+2,695% YTD), led by Backed, Ondo, Dinari, and Robinhood (tokenizing on Arbitrum). Onchain perp DEX volume rose, with Solana DEX volume surpassing CEXs in Q3; Oct 10 flash crash slowed but didn't reverse the trend. Major banks and asset managers tokenized funds, issued regulated stablecoins, and integrated blockchain settlement rails. JPMorgan launched a tokenized money‑market fund on Ethereum; SoFi issued a public stablecoin (SoFiUSD); Goldman, BNY Mellon, Deutsche Bank, BNP Paribas, HSBC, and Standard Chartered expanded custody, tokenization, or privacy‑chain participation. Fintechs added market infrastructure (Robinhood tokenized stocks, Revolut joined Pyth, Mastercard + Chainlink integration, Visa settlements using USDC). TradFi asset managers added ~$5.4B on‑chain; PayPal PYUSD grew ~8× to $4B. The chart is sourced from RWA.XYZ and Re7 Capital."}]},{"post_id":311213,"post_link":"https://insights4vc.substack.com/p/prediction-markets-at-scale-2026","published_date":"2025-12-23T21:10:07+00:00","title":"Prediction Markets at Scale: 2026 Outlook","source_name":"insights vc ","source_author":"insights vc ","summary":"Regulatory tolerance now determines scale. Prediction markets grew sharply in 2025 as mainstream brokerages and sportsbooks (Robinhood, DraftKings, FanDuel) rolled out event contracts and on-chain venues (Polymarket, Opinion Trade) amassed billions in notional volume. Growth is colliding with U.S. and state-level enforcement (CT, NV), pushing firms to design products around jurisdictional compliance, settlement definitions, and KYC/AML. The 2026 FIFA World Cup is a full-stack stress test for liquidity, settlement, payments (USDC/USDC-on-chain pilots), and distribution — likely forcing consolidation, tighter standards, or exits.","key_points":[{"header":"Core thesis","bullets":["Scale now driven by regulatory tolerance and distribution, not pure product novelty.","Platforms that prove compliant, robust settlement, and wide distribution gain durable advantage.","The 2026 World Cup is a five-week operational and regulatory stress test for markets."]},{"header":"Regulatory landscape","bullets":["CFTC allowed a narrow class of event contracts; political markets remain contested.","State actions (Connecticut, Nevada) issued cease-and-desist orders against sports-like markets.","Jurisdictional rollout, contract wording, and settlement design now prioritize legal classification."]},{"header":"On-chain vs regulated","bullets":["Polymarket and other crypto venues delivered huge volumes but faced enforcement and geofencing.","On-chain benefits: rapid market creation, 24/7 settlement, global liquidity; downsides: oracle/governance disputes and enforcement risk.","Successful on-chain players must pair rapid access with compliance guardrails or accept restricted jurisdictional footprints."]},{"header":"User and volume dynamics","bullets":["Sports drive continuous flow with many small bets; politics/macro attract larger, capital-driven positions.","2025 notional volume expanded ~10x versus 2024, ~ $13B/month by late 2025 per industry estimates.","Integrity risks concentrate in capital-heavy non-sports markets; governance disputes scale with open interest."]},{"header":"Payments and distribution","bullets":["Stablecoins (USDC) becoming settlement middleware; Visa/USDC pilots enable 24/7 bank settlement.","Super-app distribution (brokerages, sportsbooks) is the dominant moat for liquidity and trust.","Consumer token models (Sport.Fun) show token sales post-product-market-fit, an 'ICO 2.0' pattern."]}],"projects":[{"project_id":1615,"project_name":"BNB"},{"project_id":13687,"project_name":"USDC"},{"project_id":15075,"project_name":"Robinhood"},{"project_id":15096,"project_name":"Kraken"},{"project_id":21800,"project_name":"Polymarket"},{"project_id":23388,"project_name":"Circle"},{"project_id":24867,"project_name":"Brevis"},{"project_id":27120,"project_name":"Kalshi"},{"project_id":27949,"project_name":"Crypto.com"}],"images":[{"url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1766527718/veldt/pecgi2qzajanmakeo0kd.jpg","title":"Prediction Market Platforms: Regime, Core Product, Distribution, and Key Risks","description":"This image is a table comparing various prediction market platforms, outlining their regulatory regime and licensing, core product offerings, distribution models, and key risks. The platforms listed include Kalshi (US), FanDuel \"Predicts\" (US), DraftKings \"Predictions\" (US), Polymarket (Global), Betfair Exchange (UK), and Robinhood \"Prediction Markets Hub\" (US). Kalshi operates as a CFTC-regulated exchange with no sports betting license, offering event futures on economics, politics, and sports, with a direct retail platform and faces regulatory constraints and state-level legal challenges. FanDuel \"Predicts\" is CFTC-regulated via a CME event market, without a state sports betting license in launch states, offering sports and macro event contracts, and leverages its existing sportsbook user base, facing state regulatory issues and user confusion. DraftKings \"Predictions\" is CFTC-regulated via CME, offering sports event contracts, and uses its app and web platform, facing similar regulatory risks and competition. Polymarket is largely unregulated, offering decentralized prediction markets, using a Crypto/Web3 native interface, and faces regulatory enforcement and reputational risks. Betfair Exchange is UK Gambling Commission licensed, offering peer-to-peer betting, with direct-to-consumer distribution, and faces regulatory changes. Robinhood \"Prediction Markets Hub\" operates via CFTC-registered FCM and DCM, offering integrated event contracts, with a large user base, and faces regulatory arbitrage risks."},{"url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1766527958/veldt/htoo2k2cfdztczj1e4wb.jpg","title":"Prediction Market Transactions Growth","description":"This chart illustrates the growth of prediction market transactions from April 2024 to late 2025. The y-axis represents transactions, scaled up to 10 million. The x-axis represents time, with labels for April 2024, August 2024, December 2024, April 2025, and August 2025. The chart is a stacked bar chart, with each color representing a different prediction market platform: Kalshi (green), Myriad (purple), Limitless (yellow), Polymarket (blue), Opinion (orange), and Predict (dark blue). The chart begins with low transaction volumes in April 2024, with a gradual increase through August 2024. A more significant increase is observed from August 2025 onwards, with a sharp spike in late 2025. The dominant platform appears to be Polymarket, contributing the largest portion of transactions, followed by Kalshi. The chart visually represents the rapid growth and increasing adoption of prediction markets over the observed period."}]},{"post_id":317613,"post_link":"https://github.com/kuchin/awesome-ceo","published_date":"2025-12-28T00:00:00+00:00","title":"Awesome CEO: Startup Founder & Leader Resources","source_name":"kuchin","source_author":"kuchin","summary":"This repository, \"Awesome CEO,\" is a curated and opinionated list of resources for startup founders and leaders of high-growth companies. The collection includes guides from YCombinator, Dropbox, Stripe, and a16z, along with insights from prominent figures like Sam Altman and Peter Thiel. It also features tools like equity dilution calculators, angel investor directories, and pitch deck collections. The resource emphasizes practical advice for navigating startup challenges, building strong teams, and achieving product-market fit. Key point: Curated resources for startup founders and leaders.","key_points":[{"header":"Comprehensive Startup Resource Categories","bullets":["The repository organizes resources into key areas: Fundraising, Entrepreneurship, Product, Sales, Marketing, Management, Hiring, and Finance.","Each section contains curated links to articles, guides, and tools from reputable sources like YCombinator, a16z, Stripe, and industry leaders.","It provides practical advice and frameworks for various stages of startup development and leadership challenges."]},{"header":"Fundraising and Financial Guidance","bullets":["Includes guides on seed fundraising, pitch deck creation, and insights into VC expectations and valuation discussions.","Offers tools like equity dilution calculators and directories of angel investors (First Round Capital, NFX).","Covers financial planning, budgeting, and negotiation strategies for suppliers."]},{"header":"Product Development and Management Best Practices","bullets":["Emphasizes Marty Cagan's framework for product solutions: valuable, usable, feasible, and viable.","Provides resources on achieving product-market fit and conducting effective customer interviews (The Mom Test).","Features insights on effective executive leadership, team management, and building strong company culture."]}],"projects":[],"images":[]},{"post_id":300829,"post_link":"https://decentralised.co/p/payments-in-the-agentic-economy","published_date":"2025-12-19T13:58:59+00:00","title":"Payments in the Agentic Economy","source_name":"decentralised.co","source_author":"decentralised.co","summary":"Stablecoins + HTTP 402 enable machine-to-machine micropayments, but agentic commerce lacks trust infrastructure. x402 (HTTP 402 revival) and pay-per-crawl make pay-per-request practical; OpenAI's ACP and Google's AP2/Agent2Agent provide intent/auth flows. Card rails offer dispute protections but are slow and expensive; crypto rails are fast/cheap but irreversible. Key missing layers: Know-Your-Agent identity, shared fraud detection (fraud graph), reputation, and recourse/escrow (deferred settlement). Startups can wedge into identity, recourse (insurance/escrow), and attribution; incumbents (Visa/Stripe/Cloudflare/AI labs) have distribution or data advantages but misaligned incentives.","key_points":[{"header":"Key insight","bullets":["Stablecoins+HTTP 402 enable instant, low-cost micropayments for AI agents.","Trust infrastructure (identity, fraud detection, recourse) is missing for agentic payments.","Startups can capture value by productising identity, escrow/recourse, and attribution layers."]},{"header":"Current standards","bullets":["OpenAI's ACP connects agents to merchants while keeping humans in checkout loops.","Google's A2A and AP2 aim for agent interoperability, tool access (MCP), and payments.","x402 (Coinbase/Cloudflare implementations) turns HTTP 402 into pay-per-request micropayments."]},{"header":"Rails tradeoffs","bullets":["Card networks provide dispute resolution and broad distribution but are slow and costly.","Crypto rails settle in seconds at low cost but are irreversible and lack chargeback mechanisms.","x402 on chains like Base offers sub-second response and minimal nominal gas costs."]},{"header":"Trust gap components","bullets":["Identity: no persistent KYA (Know Your Agent) layer linking agents to humans/orgs.","Fraud detection: no shared fraud graph to flag anomalous agent behaviour.","Recourse: need deferred settlement/escrow or insurance to enable reversible outcomes."]},{"header":"Opportunities & trajectory","bullets":["Phase 1: agent as interface — incumbents control distribution (ACP integrations).","Phase 2: supervised execution — demand for identity and recourse; User Action: Add payment method to API provider (KYC required -> Delays access, requires approval); 3. User Action: Buy credits / subscription (Prepaid commitment -> Overpay or run out of funds); 4. User Action: Manage API key (Security risk -> Must store & rotate keys); 5. User Action: Make payment (Slow transactions, chargebacks, fees). The \"PROCESS WITH X402\" streamlines the process with three steps: 1. Agentic Action: AI agent sends HTTP request and receives 402 (Payment Required) (No account setup, instant onboarding); 2. Agentic Action: AI agent pays seamlessly with stablecoins, no signups or approvals required; 3. Agentic Action: API access granted (No manual approvals, no API key management). Nexus encodes workflows onchain, Leaders run offchain tools and submit cryptographic receipts, and tools register pricing and access. Design priorities: deterministic, auditable state transitions; hybrid onchain/offchain execution; delivery-versus-payment gas budgeting; progressive decentralization of Leaders; and economic primitives to enable agent-to-agent markets and custody of assets.","key_points":[{"header":"Problem Talus Solves","bullets":["Centralized AI infra is opaque, brittle, and unsuitable for multi-party autonomous agents.","Agents need persistence, verifiability, cryptographic permissions, and native economic participation.","Current API/model providers create dependency, unpredictable pricing, and no auditable proofs."]},{"header":"Core Architecture","bullets":["Nexus stores workflow DAGs and state transitions on Sui using Move and object-centric state.","Leaders coordinate offchain compute, execute tools, and submit verifiable receipts onchain.","Walrus provides decentralized offchain storage with onchain commitments for large agent memory."]},{"header":"Execution Model","bullets":["Workflows encoded as DAGs: nodes are tool invocations or state updates; executions tracked as DAGExecution objects.","Walk states (Active, Successful, Failed, Consumed) provide liveness, fallbacks, and error handling.","Offchain compute performs heavy tasks; cryptographic commitments settle results onchain for auditability."]},{"header":"Economic & Security Primitives","bullets":["$US token used for payments, staking, governance, tool registration, and Leader participation.","Gas budget pre-funds possible costs; delivery-versus-payment releases funds after verification.","Leaders stake collateral and face slashing; initial trusted Leaders evolve toward TEEs and permissionless staking."]},{"header":"Use Cases & Limits","bullets":["Use cases: verifiable prediction markets, MEV protection bots, cross-chain portfolios, accountable DAO treasuries.","Limits: verification adds latency, complex multi-agent debugging, incentive misalignment and temporary centralization risks.","Privacy possible via TEEs and ZK-ML; cross-chain proofs reduce custodial bridge reliance."]}],"projects":[{"project_id":813,"project_name":"Arbitrum"},{"project_id":4694,"project_name":"Ethereum"},{"project_id":12556,"project_name":"Sui"},{"project_id":22123,"project_name":"Walrus"},{"project_id":40695,"project_name":"Talus"}],"images":[{"url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1766088713/veldt/ql8d1yqnstmkv85ryvxw.jpg","title":"Talus's Stack Architecture","description":"The image is a diagram illustrating Talus's stack architecture, detailing the core components of the Talus Network. The architecture is divided into several layers and components, showcasing the flow of data and operations. At the top, \"Agent Applications\" interact with \"Workflow Triggers\" which then connect to \"Agent Packages TAP\" and \"Developer Tools SDK\" that feed into the \"On-Chain Coordination\" layer. The \"On-Chain Coordination\" layer includes \"Workflow Engine\" and \"Tool Registry\" components. The \"Workflow Engine\" interacts with \"Nexus\" and \"Gas Service\" components, while the \"Tool Registry\" interacts with the \"Gas Service\". The \"Leader Network\" layer is connected to the \"On-Chain Coordination\" layer and includes \"Offchain Hub\". The \"Leader Network\" interacts with \"Walrus\" (Offchain Storage) and the \"Tool Execution Layer\". The \"Tool Execution Layer\" includes \"ML/AI Models\", \"Price Oracles\", \"Gas Service (Privacy)\", and \"Risk Calculations\". The \"Tool Execution Layer\" sends \"Results to Apps\" and also provides \"Back to Leader Network\". The diagram also shows the flow of events, including \"Events Emitted\", \"Monitor Events\", \"Coordinate Execution\", \"Execute Tools\", \"Submit Receipts\", and \"Store/Retrieve\". The diagram also highlights that off-chain compute handles intensive operations. The diagram is a visual representation of the Talus Network's architecture, showing the interaction between on-chain and off-chain components."},{"url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1766088651/veldt/e0cy4iwr4ofwf9mbiqmo.jpg","title":"Nexus Architecture and Workflow Diagram","description":"This diagram illustrates the Nexus architecture and workflow within the Talus stack. Crypto's infrastructure phase is ending as abundant, low-cost blockspace compresses protocol economics. Ethereum scaling produced ~95% fee decline, exposing oversupply and thin protocol fee capture. Blockchains hold >90% market value while capturing <<12% of fees; DeFi captures >70% of fees but accounts for <<10% market cap. Expect a multi-year re-rating: infrastructure multiples fall, user-facing aggregators and apps re-rate up as value migrates to distribution and real-world revenue. Macro positioning and fee volatility increase downside probability near-term.","key_points":[{"header":"End of Infrastructure Phase","bullets":["Infrastructure built: fast chains, cheap execution, abundant blockspace.","Technical scarcity largely solved; marginal cost of computation collapsed.","Network reliability now resembles commoditized infrastructure, not frontier innovation.","Main problem shifts from building rails to generating recurring demand."]},{"header":"Economics of Abundance","bullets":["Ethereum scaling drove roughly a 95% decline in fees, enlarging consumer surplus.","Lower costs benefit users but remove pricing power from infrastructure providers.","Open-source replication creates oversupply: many blockchains, too few paying users.","Abundance compresses margins and undermines protocol-level economic leverage."]},{"header":"The Great Re-Rating","bullets":["Current mismatch: Blockchains ≫90% market cap but retain ≪12% of fees.","DeFi captures ≫70% of fees yet represents ≪10% of market capitalization.","Valuation and fee capture should converge; expect infrastructure multiples to decline.","Pair-trade thesis: short infrastructure, long user-facing aggregators and apps."]},{"header":"Adoption, Moats, Rail Effects","bullets":["Real-world adoption (stablecoins, payments rails) reduces frictions but often benefits incumbents.","Value accrues at distribution and offramps, not the rails themselves.","First-mover protocol moats are fragile: liquidity and users are incentive-sensitive.","DEX markets show incumbents can rapidly lose share despite persistent mindshare."]},{"header":"Market Implications","bullets":["Crypto priced for perfection increases mean-reversion downside probability.","Fee volatility implies revenue is cyclical and levered to macro conditions.","Investable opportunity: crypto-enabled businesses with real revenue and distribution.","Regulatory plumbing (e.g., Fed proposals) and stablecoin adoption are key catalysts."]}],"projects":[{"project_id":4694,"project_name":"Ethereum"}],"images":[{"url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1766508020/veldt/u8nxlkhgqbtaxucjee53.jpg","title":"Price-to-Fee Ratios by Sector","description":"This chart visualizes Price-to-Fee Ratios by Sector, presenting median values with interquartile ranges for DeFi/Finance and Blockchains. Runner-ups include MiniMax M2, GLM-4.5, GPT-OSS, Gemma 3, and Olmo 3. Honorable mentions: Parakeet 3, Nemotron 2, Moondream 3, Granite 4, SmolLM3. Tier list ranks Frontier labs, noteworthy contributors, specialists, and rising orgs. Predictions: open-model deployments scale further in 2026, though closed models keep advantages in robustness and real-world richness.","key_points":[{"header":"Key takeaway","bullets":["2025 marked a turning point: open models rival closed models on many benchmarks.","Open releases broadened beyond niche use-cases into mainstream deployment possibilities.","Closed models still lead in robustness and real-world behavior despite benchmark parity."]},{"header":"Top models of 2025","bullets":["DeepSeek R1 — released Jan 20, MIT license; Selig, viewed as pro-crypto, will serve until April 2029 and says he will favor pro‑innovation, non‑enforcement‑first oversight as Congress moves toward digital asset market-structure legislation.","bullets":["Michael Selig was sworn in as CFTC chairman and will serve a term through April 2029 after a presidential nomination and Senate confirmation.","Caroline Pham, the CFTC’s acting chair and sole commissioner for part of 2025, departs the agency and is reported to be joining MoonPay.","Selig is broadly perceived as pro-crypto and pledges to support innovation while avoiding 'regulation by enforcement'; his prior roles include chief counsel for the SEC’s Crypto Task Force.","Selig’s arrival leaves him as the CFTC’s sole commissioner and coincides with anticipated congressional digital asset market-structure legislation."],"projects":[{"project_id":1615,"project_name":"BNB"},{"project_id":1701,"project_name":"Bitcoin"},{"project_id":4694,"project_name":"Ethereum"},{"project_id":11943,"project_name":"Solana"},{"project_id":23682,"project_name":"MoonPay"}]},{"post_id":293868,"post_link":"https://macrocosmosai.substack.com/p/guest-post-bittensor-drives-unstoppable","published_date":"2025-12-16T19:28:20+00:00","title":"Bittensor subnet Yanez for adversarial AML data","source_name":"Macrocosmos","source_author":"Macrocosmos","summary":"Yanez (SN54), a Bittensor subnet, builds continuous synthetic adversarial datasets for financial crime prevention: inorganic identities, deepfake-resistant biometrics, sanctions-name variations, forged documents, and adversarial transaction flows. Continuous adversarial data addresses model degradation and regulatory expectations (OCC, NYDFS, FCA) by enabling regular stress tests, subscription revenue for data-as-a-service, and improved AML/KYC resilience for banks, IDV firms, and compliance vendors.","key_points":[{"header":"Key proposition","bullets":["Yanez (SN54) is a Bittensor subnet generating adversarial, synthetic identity and transaction datasets.","Targets banks, IDV vendors, and compliance tools with continuous stress-testing and model validation data.","Produces synthetic biometrics, deepfake-resistant variants, sanctions/name permutations, forged documents, and identity clusters."]},{"header":"Why adversarial data matters","bullets":["Real-world rare attacks (deepfakes, forged docs, sanctions evasion) are absent or unshareable in production data.","Other industries (autonomous driving, cybersecurity, biometrics) improved only after adversarial datasets emerged.","Adversarial corpora reveal edge-case failures that determine deployed model safety and compliance."]},{"header":"Product & market fit","bullets":["Continuous generation aligns with regulators' expectations for ongoing model validation and testing.","SaaS/subscription model ties revenue to recurring needs: resilience, reporting, and audit trails.","Large TAM: banks spend on identity, AML, KYC, sanctions screening; gap exists in adversarial dataset supply."]},{"header":"Technical & operational benefits","bullets":["Enables stress tests across sanctions screening, transaction monitoring, KYC/KYB, and identity verification.","Cloud-agnostic SaaS with quick, actionable results and corrective workflow and risk reporting outputs.","Decentralized subnet design incentivizes dataset generation and continuous evolution of attack scenarios."]}],"projects":[{"project_id":1790,"project_name":"Bittensor"},{"project_id":21790,"project_name":"Metanova"}],"images":[{"url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1765916638/veldt/ch5uf4itwlk7eilplzje.jpg","title":"Financial Crime Prevention System Diagram","description":"This infographic illustrates a financial crime prevention system, highlighting its components and functionalities. The system utilizes \"Yanez Adversarial Data,\" \"Compliance Frameworks,\" and a \"Risk Scenario Library\" as inputs. These inputs feed into a \"Synthetic Data Test,\" which undergoes a \"Stress Test\" to evaluate the \"Financial Crime Prevention Systems.\" The prevention systems include \"Sanctions Screening,\" \"Transaction Monitoring,\" \"KYC / KYB,\" and \"Identity Verification.\" The system outputs include \"Corrective Workflows,\" \"Compliance Reports,\" and \"Risk Reports.\" The diagram also lists key features: actively stress testing financial crime prevention systems, confirming correct system operations and configuration, detecting weaknesses and misconfigurations, proactively correcting deficiencies, SaaS and cloud agnostic for local deployments, no IT resources required (SaaS), and actionable results in minutes."},{"url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1765916697/veldt/dw7bluhizpyu4jp8m4ry.jpg","title":"Financial Crime Prevention Infographic","description":"This infographic highlights the importance of financial crime prevention. The second section focuses on the financial impact of financial crime, stating that it \"hurts, a lot.\" It includes the figures of $2T for money laundering and $450B for fraud loss. The third section addresses regulatory pressure, with $315B in fines over the last 15 years. The fifth section presents the competitive advantage of financial crime prevention, quoting a compliance officer from a Tier 1 bank: \"I can enable more business faster.\""}]},{"post_id":293025,"post_link":"https://re7research.substack.com/p/the-weekly-16th-december-2025","published_date":"2025-12-16T13:16:17+00:00","title":"Revisiting L1 Valuations: Flows, Not Revenue","source_name":"Re7 Research","source_author":"Re7 Research","summary":"Liquidity and capital flows, not on-chain revenue, are the primary drivers of Layer-1 token valuations. Price-to-revenue multiples for L1s have averaged >500 over six years, signalling valuations decoupled from cash flows. Network activity and user metrics are often second-order effects produced by capital deployment into ecosystems (ETH, TRX, NEAR, BTC). Macroeconomic conditions (US ISM, risk appetite, monetary policy) correlate with L1 valuation cycles. Valuation dispersion across chains reflects which ecosystems attract the largest flows based on product, traction, and narrative.","key_points":[{"header":"Core Thesis","bullets":["Primary driver of L1 valuations is capital flows and liquidity, not protocol revenue.","Users, adoption, and revenue are second-order effects of where capital is deployed.","Macroeconomic conditions change risk appetite and therefore capital flows into crypto."]},{"header":"Evidence & Metrics","bullets":["Average price-to-revenue multiple for L1s >500 across six years, inconsistent with revenue-driven valuation.","Metcalfe-style user metrics correlate with market cap but often follow price, not lead it.","Charts show ETH, TRX, NEAR ratios versus US ISM aligning value with macro cycles."]},{"header":"Flow Mechanism","bullets":["Economic expansion raises investor income, lowers risk premia, and increases capital to risky assets like crypto.","Inflows to ETH and ecosystem capital deployment amplify on-chain activity across DeFi, L2s, staking.","Narrative strength and product traction concentrate liquidity into specific chains."]},{"header":"Implications for Investors","bullets":["Valuation models should weight macro-driven flows and narrative dominance over pure fee capture.","Comparative strength between L1s depends on which capture the largest capital allocation.","Short-term price moves also reflect non-macro shocks: liquidations, token unlocks, tariff headlines."]},{"header":"Closing Remarks","bullets":["The L1 valuation debate lacks a tidy answer because flows dominate multiple channels.","Focus research on liquidity sources, macro drivers, and narrative traction for better valuation insight."]}],"projects":[{"project_id":1701,"project_name":"Bitcoin"},{"project_id":4694,"project_name":"Ethereum"},{"project_id":8971,"project_name":"NEAR The draft would treat regulated dollar‑pegged payment stablecoins as cash, apply wash‑sale and constructive sale rules to digital assets, extend securities‑lending tax treatment to qualifying crypto loans, and allow certain dealers to elect mark‑to‑market accounting. It also seeks clarity on staking, mining rewards, charitable donations, and tax treatment for foreign investors trading on U.S. platforms. The draft is positioned as a request for feedback ahead of formal legislation.","bullets":["Bipartisan discussion draft named PARITY Act proposes aligning digital asset taxation with existing rules for stocks and commodities.","Key provisions: stablecoins treated as cash, application of wash‑sale/constructive sale rules, mark‑to‑market election for professional dealers, and clarified staking/mining tax timing.","Proposal aims to reduce compliance burdens for routine transactions while closing gaps enabling tax avoidance.","Draft seeks feedback and may ease everyday crypto use but progress depends on congressional dynamics and broader crypto oversight debates."],"projects":[]},{"news_id":145273,"url":"https://cointelegraph.com/news/ghana-passes-law-to-legalize-crypto-trading-central-bank-governor-says","post_date":"2025-12-22T13:40:22.894+00:00","title":"Ghana passes law to legalize crypto trading, central bank governor says","source_name":"Cointelegraph","summary":"Ghana's parliament passed the Virtual Asset Service Providers Bill into law, legalizing crypto trading and granting the Bank of Ghana authority to license and supervise crypto asset service providers. The law aims to reduce fraud, money laundering and systemic risk while supporting innovation and financial inclusion for youth and tech entrepreneurs. Chainalysis data cited in the report highlights Ghana's rising crypto adoption within Sub-Saharan Africa.","bullets":["Parliament enacts the Virtual Asset Service Providers Bill, making virtual asset trading legal in Ghana.","Bank of Ghana becomes the primary regulator with licensing and supervisory powers over crypto asset service providers (CASPs).","Legislation targets fraud, money laundering and systemic risks, and aims to foster innovation and financial inclusion.","Cointelegraph cites Chainalysis data showing Ghana among top five Sub-Saharan African countries by crypto value received (July 2024–June 2025)."],"projects":[{"project_id":1615,"project_name":"BNB"},{"project_id":1701,"project_name":"Bitcoin"},{"project_id":4694,"project_name":"Ethereum"},{"project_id":11943,"project_name":"Solana"},{"project_id":23459,"project_name":"Chainalysis"}]},{"news_id":145230,"url":"https://cointelegraph.com/news/us-lawmakers-push-to-fix-staking-double-taxation-before-2026","post_date":"2025-12-22T04:28:57.903+00:00","title":"US lawmakers push to fix staking 'double taxation' before 2026","source_name":"Cointelegraph","summary":"A bipartisan group of 18 U.S. House lawmakers led by Republican Mike Carey asks the IRS to review and update guidance on crypto staking taxes before 2026 to end what they call 'double taxation' of staking rewards. They propose taxing staking rewards at sale (reflecting actual economic gain) or allowing taxpayers to defer recognition of staking and mining rewards for up to five years. The effort is part of broader congressional moves to ease crypto tax burdens, including parallel drafts to exempt small stablecoin transactions from capital gains.","bullets":["18 bipartisan House members request the IRS to revisit staking tax rules to eliminate 'double taxation' on staking rewards.","Lawmakers propose taxing staking rewards at time of sale or offering a deferral election (up to five years) for staking/mining rewards.","The letter argues current rules create administrative burdens and discourage staking, threatening network security and U.S. leadership in digital assets.","Separate House proposals seek additional tax relief such as exempting small stablecoin transactions from capital gains."],"projects":[{"project_id":1615,"project_name":"BNB"},{"project_id":1701,"project_name":"Bitcoin"},{"project_id":2510,"project_name":"Cardano"},{"project_id":4694,"project_name":"Ethereum"},{"project_id":11943,"project_name":"Solana"},{"project_id":13386,"project_name":"TRON"},{"project_id":15096,"project_name":"Kraken"}]},{"post_id":301168,"post_link":"https://coinbase.com/institutional/research-insights/research/market-intelligence/2026-crypto-market-outlook","published_date":"2025-12-19T23:59:59+00:00","title":"2026 Crypto Market Outlook","source_name":null,"source_author":null,"summary":"Crypto markets poised for transformative growth in 2026 as clearer regulation and institutional integration deepen crypto’s role in core finance. growth in ZK proofs and fully homomorphic encryption for institutional confidentiality.","AI‑driven agent systems need programmable, high‑frequency settlement (microtransactions) and supporting protocols.","Proliferation of application‑specific chains leads to network-of-networks with native interoperability and shared security."]},{"header":"Product and markets","bullets":["Composability of derivatives: perpetuals evolving into core DeFi primitives integrated with lending and hedging.","Prediction markets expected to expand volumes; aggregators could consolidate large weekly flows.","Stablecoins dominate utility; stochastic model projects ~ $1.2T stablecoin market cap central target by 2028."]},{"header":"Risks and catalysts","bullets":["Major platform upgrades (Ethereum Fusaka, Solana Alpenglow) and bitcoin cycle dynamics are key catalysts.","Quantum computing poses systemic security risk; execution, regulation, and product quality determine outcomes.","Real‑world asset tokenization offers high upside if compliance, custody, and composability challenges are solved."]}],"projects":[{"project_id":1701,"project_name":"Bitcoin"},{"project_id":4694,"project_name":"Ethereum"},{"project_id":11943,"project_name":"Solana"}],"images":[]},{"news_id":144970,"url":"https://www.theblock.co/post/383083/senate-confirm-cftc-chair-michael-selig","post_date":"2025-12-19T01:29:26.796+00:00","title":"Senate confirms CFTC Chair pick Michael Selig as agency takes larger role regulating crypto","source_name":"The Block","summary":"The U.S. Senate confirmed Michael Selig to lead the Commodity Futures Trading Commission in a 53-43 vote, positioning the CFTC to play a larger role in federal crypto regulation as Congress considers bills expanding its authority. Selig, with prior SEC crypto task force experience and private-sector crypto legal work, says clearer rules are needed while balancing consumer protection and innovation. Industry and some officials welcomed the confirmation amid discussions about CFTC resourcing relative to the SEC.","bullets":["Senate voted 53-43 to advance/confirm Michael Selig as CFTC Chair on Dec. 18, 2025.","Selig previously served as SEC chief counsel for its Crypto Task Force and worked in private crypto law practice.","Confirmation comes while Congress considers legislation that could expand the CFTC's regulatory authority over digital commodities.","Industry figures and lawmakers expressed cautious optimism about clearer rules and pragmatic regulation; funding needs for CFTC were discussed."],"projects":[{"project_id":23906,"project_name":"Sec3"}]},{"post_id":296907,"post_link":"https://vitalik.eth.limo/general/2025/12/17/societies.html","published_date":"2025-12-17T23:59:59+00:00","title":"Let a thousand societies bloom","source_name":"Vitalik","source_author":"Vitalik","summary":"Advocate building pluralistic, experimental communities—popups, hubs, tribes and jurisdictional \"zones\"—to accelerate cultural and governance innovation. Popups (≈200 people, 1–2 months) are effective prototypes but have limits: cost, shallow immersion, poor local integration, and governance fade. Permanent hubs and zones enable deeper cultural instantiation, experiments in law (vouching/insurance), novel governance (liquid/multi-tier delegation), and targeted economic policy. Recommend separating roles (tribes vs zones), fostering physical nodes, collective visas, and iterative, local experiments to distribute talent and test policy without national-scale risk.","key_points":[{"header":"Key experiment takeaways","bullets":["Popups of ~200 people for 1–2 months are strong prototypes for cultural testing.","Optimal popup duration: two months — forms subcultures while avoiding burnout.","Popups often regress: become shorter, smaller, and more generic over time.","Permanent nodes/hubs required to preserve depth, culture, and governance innovation."]},{"header":"Tribes, culture, governance","bullets":["Successful intermediate institutions focus on culture as functional practices, not just aesthetics.","Avoid three failures: top-down imposition, pure preservation, or pure individualist drift.","Tribes can prototype governance using culture plus tech (blockchains, ZK, AI) to reduce attention and social-game problems.","Prefigurational cultures and immersion enable deep habit and public-good formation."]},{"header":"Hubs and physical spaces","bullets":["Hubs instantiate values via built infrastructure: food, energy, open hardware, communal rooms.","Small hubs inside cities can be viable; rural hubs require larger scale to sustain amenities.","Examples: Frontier Tower, Crecimiento, 4seas nodes, Prospera, Gelephu Mindfulness City.","Hubs allow long-term cultural learning and training ground for governance experimentation."]},{"header":"Zones and legal experiments","bullets":["Zones pursue rule innovation: vouching/mandatory liability insurance and relaxed urban policy.","Zones are politically palatable to host countries and can capture economic spillovers.","Policy experiments include urbanism reforms, collective visas, and calibrated autonomy.","Zones preferred over creating new countries due to sovereignty constraints and scalability."]},{"header":"Risks and market structure","bullets":["Risks: elitism, neo-colonialism, regulatory arbitrage, and capture at scale.","Mitigations: limited scale, transparency, cooperation with host governments, and benefit-sharing.","Market will split roles: tribes/hubs (culture) vs zones (policy/legal frameworks).","Aim to import networks, not just individuals; collective visas and vetted tribe admission recommended."]}],"projects":[{"project_id":4694,"project_name":"Ethereum"},{"project_id":7460,"project_name":"Liberland LLD"},{"project_id":10541,"project_name":"Prospera Tax Credit"},{"project_id":31393,"project_name":"Praxis"},{"project_id":43929,"project_name":"Gelephu Mindfulness City"}],"images":[]},{"news_id":145096,"url":"https://www.bankless.com/read/news/michael-selig-confirmed-as-cftc-chair","post_date":"2025-12-19T18:42:28+00:00","title":"Michael Selig Confirmed as CFTC Chair","source_name":"Bankless","summary":"The U.S. Senate confirmed Michael Selig as Chair of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission on December 18, 2025. Selig, currently Chief Counsel of the SEC's Crypto Task Force, is widely viewed as a pro-crypto pick and will replace acting Chair Caroline Pham. His confirmation is expected to accelerate coordination between the CFTC and SEC on digital asset regulatory clarity.","bullets":["Senate confirmed Michael Selig as CFTC Chair on Dec 18, 2025.","Selig is currently Chief Counsel of the SEC’s Crypto Task Force and considered pro-crypto.","He will replace acting Chair Caroline Pham, who is moving to MoonPay.","Market and policy watchers expect improved coordination between CFTC and SEC on digital asset rules."],"projects":[{"project_id":23682,"project_name":"MoonPay"}]},{"news_id":145006,"url":"https://www.dlnews.com/articles/regulation/us-senate-confirms-crypto-ally-mike-selig-to-lead-cftc/","post_date":"2025-12-19T09:22:51.259+00:00","title":"US Senate confirms crypto ally Mike Selig to lead CFTC","source_name":"DL News","summary":"The US Senate confirmed Mike Selig as chair of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC). Selig, a former SEC Crypto Task Force chief counsel and Trump nominee, pledges a pro-crypto, light-touch approach while stressing the need for clearer crypto laws. His confirmation arrives amid negotiations over a market-structure bill that could shift primary crypto oversight to the CFTC and follows questions about CFTC staffing and jurisdiction over prediction markets.","bullets":["Senate confirmed Mike Selig 53-43 to lead the CFTC; he replaces interim chair Caroline Pham.","Selig served as chief counsel at the SEC’s Crypto Task Force and has signaled pro-crypto, light-touch regulatory views.","Confirmation coincides with a draft market-structure bill that could make the CFTC the primary crypto regulator and raises staffing concerns.","Selig dodged firm answers on prediction markets and committed to seeking diverse viewpoints and facilitating well-functioning commodity markets."],"projects":[]},{"post_id":294566,"post_link":"https://implications.com/p/the-era-of-summarized-living-what","published_date":"2025-12-16T20:18:39+00:00","title":"The Era of Summarized Living","source_name":"Implications","source_author":"Implications","summary":"Daily life and work will be captured, summarized, and analyzed by always-on AI memories, creating permanent private summaries that improve accountability, reduce biased recollection, and change social norms. Summarization (not verbatim records) will shift attribution, meeting behavior, and document-retention practices. Products that let users 'flex' — creative, skill, wit, cultural, and status flexes — retain engagement; successful designs enable passive, authentic flex. Augmented reality (AR) remains a long‑term interface bet — breakthrough adoption requires visible new consumer behaviors. Ethical, cultural, and ownership questions arise around shared memories and access.","key_points":[{"header":"Core thesis","bullets":["Everyday conversations increasingly summarized into intelligent, private memories accessible like an extension of the brain.","Summaries, not verbatim transcripts, will become the canonical record used for decisions and accountability.","Summarized Living reduces memory bias, improving meritocracy while raising new privacy and cultural questions."]},{"header":"Product implications","bullets":["Next‑gen devices and apps (Plaud, Limitless, Granola, Notion/Atlassian features) will focus on analysis, mind maps, and actionable captures.","Designs must anticipate people optimizing speech for better summarization and search (trigger words, careful attribution).","Enterprises will revisit retention policies and employees will alter communication knowing AI summaries persist."]},{"header":"Behavioral and ethical issues","bullets":["Shared memory access prompts etiquette questions: who can search colleagues’ summaries and who owns memories after leaving?","Summaries can both protect and harm — interpretation layers may obscure verbatim nuance, affecting litigation and reputation.","Cultural norms will shift toward fact‑grounded post‑game analysis and more team‑oriented conversations."]},{"header":"Engagement and 'flex'","bullets":["Products that enable users to flex (creative, skill, wit, cultural, social/status) drive retention and virality.","Successful products make flex feel passive; features and algorithms must surface pride points without forcing performance.","Different flex types suggest feature patterns: process showcases for creativity, leaderboards for skill, constraints for wit."]},{"header":"AR outlook","bullets":["AR is the next transformational interface but still early — initial hardware (Vision Pro, Meta glasses) feel niche.","True consumer adoption requires visible, novel behaviors that make usage obvious from across the room.","AR coupled with trusted social graphs could create new social rituals and reduce loneliness by making people feel known."]}],"projects":[],"images":[]},{"news_id":144969,"url":"https://www.coindesk.com/policy/2025/12/11/senate-confirms-trump-crypto-friendly-nominees-to-take-over-cftc-fdic","post_date":"2025-12-19T01:27:36.586+00:00","title":"Senate confirms Trump crypto-friendly nominees to take over CFTC, FDIC","source_name":"CoinDesk","summary":"The U.S. Senate confirmed Mike Selig as chair of the CFTC and Travis Hill as chair of the FDIC in a mass-confirmation package. Both are viewed as crypto-friendly and could shift regulatory posture: Selig will oversee CFTC crypto rulemaking amid ongoing congressional talks to expand the agency’s crypto authority, while Hill will lead the FDIC’s approach to banks serving stablecoin issuers and address prior \"debanking\" practices.","bullets":["Senate approved Mike Selig (CFTC) and Travis Hill (FDIC) in a 53-43 mass-confirmation vote.","Selig replaces acting chair Caroline Pham and may press forward on the CFTC's \"crypto sprint,\" stablecoin/collateral rulemaking, and broader derivatives oversight of spot crypto if Congress grants expanded authority.","Hill, already acting chair, takes a formal role at the FDIC and signals a more permissive stance toward banks serving crypto firms and stablecoin issuers.","Confirmation came via a grouped resolution that bundled dozens of nominees, bypassing individual hearings; the appointments could materially affect U.S. crypto regulatory enforcement and policy direction."],"projects":[{"project_id":23400,"project_name":"Bitnomial"},{"project_id":23682,"project_name":"MoonPay"},{"project_id":24206,"project_name":"CoinDesk"}]},{"news_id":144274,"url":"https://news.bloomberglaw.com/crypto/jpmorgan-debuts-first-money-market-fund-tokenized-on-ethereum","post_date":"2025-12-15T16:17:35.008+00:00","title":"JPMorgan Debuts First Money Market Fund Tokenized on Ethereum","source_name":"Bloomberg Law News","summary":"JPMorgan Asset Management launches My OnChain Net Yield Fund (MONY), its first tokenized money market fund built on Ethereum via the bank's Kinexys Digital Assets platform. The private fund, open to qualified investors, issues a blockchain token that represents fund holdings and allows investors to earn yield while holding the token on-chain. The move signals further Wall Street adoption of tokenization for traditional asset management.","bullets":["JPMorgan Asset Management launches MONY (My OnChain Net Yield Fund), a tokenized money market fund on Ethereum.","MONY is issued via JPMorgan’s Kinexys Digital Assets tokenization platform and is available to qualified investors.","Investors can hold a token on-chain that represents the fund position and earn yield while remaining on Ethereum.","The announcement marks a notable institutional push into blockchain-based tokenization of traditional financial products."],"projects":[{"project_id":4694,"project_name":"Ethereum"}]},{"news_id":144218,"url":"https://financefeeds.com/jpmorgan-launches-100m-tokenized-money-market-fund-on-ethereum/","post_date":"2025-12-15T13:38:22.177+00:00","title":"JPMorgan Launches $100M Tokenized Money-Market Fund on Ethereum","source_name":"FinanceFeeds","summary":"JPMorgan launches My OnChain Net Yield Fund (MONY), a $100M tokenized money‑market fund on Ethereum seeded with the bank’s capital. The private vehicle issues digital tokens redeemable for cash or USDC, targets qualified investors, and is built on JPMorgan’s Kinexys tokenization platform. The move signals accelerating institutional adoption of tokenized funds on public blockchains amid clearer U.S. regulatory guidance.","bullets":["JPMorgan seeds MONY with $100 million and opens subscriptions to qualified investors via Morgan Money.","Investors receive tokens representing fund positions; subscriptions/redemptions accept cash or USDC and custody uses compatible crypto wallets.","MONY uses Kinexys Digital Assets (JPMorgan’s tokenization platform) and mirrors traditional money‑market fund mechanics.","The launch builds on regulatory clarity (GENIUS Act, Clarity Act) and follows similar institutional tokenization efforts from BlackRock, Goldman Sachs and others.","JPMorgan’s use of Ethereum (and recent work on Solana) shows large institutions testing public networks for regulated fund issuance."],"projects":[{"project_id":1819,"project_name":"BlackRock BUIDL"},{"project_id":4694,"project_name":"Ethereum"},{"project_id":11943,"project_name":"Solana"},{"project_id":13687,"project_name":"USDC"},{"project_id":29353,"project_name":"Galaxy"}]},{"news_id":144211,"url":"https://www.barrons.com/articles/jpmorgan-chase-crypto-tokenized-money-market-fund-d7df2df8","post_date":"2025-12-15T13:09:16.101+00:00","title":"JPMorgan Chase Launches Tokenized Money-Market Fund. Crypto and Wall Street Collide.","source_name":"Barron's","summary":"JPMorgan Chase is launching its first tokenized money‑market fund, My OnChain Net Yield Fund (MONY), seeding it with $100 million and offering access via its Kinexys Digital Assets platform. Bitcoin may reach a new all-time high in H1 2026 and the 20 millionth BTC will be mined in March 2026. Bipartisan U.S. market-structure legislation and the GENIUS Act on stablecoins will expand institutional access, enable on-chain issuance, and accelerate ETP inflows. Top 10 investing themes: monetary alternatives, regulatory clarity, stablecoins growth, asset tokenization, privacy, crypto+AI, DeFi lending, next‑gen infrastructure, revenue focus, and staking adoption. Quantum risk and digital asset treasuries unlikely to move markets in 2026.","key_points":[{"header":"Macro and Regulation Drivers","bullets":["Dual pillars: macro demand for scarce digital assets and clearer regulation underpin 2026 upside.","Expect bipartisan U.S. crypto market-structure legislation to pass in 2026, cementing regulated venues.","GENIUS Act passage in 2025 expands stablecoin legitimacy and institutional use cases.","Spot ETP inflows (~$87bn since Jan 2024) to continue as platforms integrate crypto into portfolios."]},{"header":"Price Outlook","bullets":["Grayscale expects rising valuations across crypto sectors and a Bitcoin all-time high in H1 2026.","Institutional buying pattern implies steadier advances versus prior 1,000% retail-driven cycles.","Federal Reserve easing and supportive macro backdrop reduce downside tail risks for 2026."]},{"header":"Top 10 Investing Themes","bullets":["Monetary alternatives: BTC, ETH, ZEC benefit from fiat debasement risk and scarce supply.","Regulatory clarity: broader on-chain issuance, balance sheet reporting, and access to regulated markets.","Stablecoins: $300bn supply and $1.1tn monthly flows drive payments, collateral, and cross-border use."]},{"header":"More Themes & Infrastructure","bullets":["Asset tokenization at inflection point; ETH, BNB, SOL leading current distributed tokenized assets.","Privacy demand grows (ZEC, Aztec, Railgun); confidential txs and identity/compliance tooling needed.","AI centralization creates demand for decentralized AI, identity, IP and micropayments primitives."]},{"header":"DeFi, Revenue, and Staking","bullets":["DeFi accelerates around lending and derivatives: AAVE, Morpho, Maple, Hyperliquid noted leaders.","Institutional focus on fee revenue as a fundamental metric for chain selection (SOL, ETH, BNB).","Staking adoption rises as SEC/IRS guidance enables ETP staking; Investment Gold (dark blue line) shows a steady increase over the period, with a more pronounced rise towards 2025. Past performance is not indicative of future results."},{"url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1765836848/veldt/o208nzvi6wrtyozlub7y.jpg","title":"Key Crypto Policy Changes by US Government in 2025","description":"This infographic outlines key crypto policy changes by the US Government in 2025. The SEC rescinded Staff Accounting Bulletin (SAB) 121, which limited the ability of traditional financial institutions to custody crypto assets in January 2025. From January to August 2025, the SEC dropped investigations and/or lawsuits into several leading crypto industry firms, including Coinbase, Ripple, Binance, Robinhood, Consensys, Uniswap, and OpenSea. In March 2025, the White House created the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and United States Digital Asset Stockpile, stating that Bitcoin in the reserve \"shall not be sold.\" The Federal Reserve, FDIC, & OCC dropped \"reputational risk\" from bank supervisory guidance from March to August 2025. In May 2025, the SEC issued staff statements that staking activities are not securities transactions. The Department of Labor & White House rescinded guidance that prevented many 401(k) plans from offering crypto assets from May to August 2025. In June 2025, the SEC withdrew proposed rules that would have brought certain smart contract-based applications, including decentralized exchanges (DEXs), under the agency's jurisdiction. In July 2025, the White House & Congress passed the GENIUS Act, providing a regulatory framework for payment stablecoins. In September 2025, the SEC approved Generic Listing Standards (GLS) for crypto exchange-traded products (ETPs). In November 2025, Treasury/IRS issued safe harbor rules for staking in crypto ETPs."}]},{"post_id":293215,"post_link":"https://alearesearch.substack.com/p/nado-unified-trading-stack-on-ink","published_date":"2025-12-16T14:30:43+00:00","title":"Nado: CLOB DEX on Ink with Unified Margin","source_name":"Revelo Intel","source_author":"Revelo Intel","summary":"Nado is a non-custodial CLOB DEX deployed on Ink L2 combining spot, perpetual futures, and integrated money markets under a unified margin and clearing engine. Offchain sequencers match orders in 5–15 ms with onchain batch settlement and an onchain risk/clearinghouse verifying exposures. NLP vaults accept USDT0 deposits to provide market-making and liquidation liquidity; NLP positions earn variable APY and can be used as collateral. Private alpha metrics: ~ $5B cumulative perp volume over three weeks, ~ $400M daily perp volume, > $40M open interest, ~1,000+ traders, and ~$20M TVL across deposits and NLP, with NLP vault capacity raised to $2M.","key_points":[{"header":"Product Overview","bullets":["CLOB DEX on Ink L2 offering spot, perps, and money markets in one orderbook.","Low-latency offchain sequencer matches bids/asks in 5–15 ms, batches for onchain settlement.","Onchain clearinghouse tracks portfolio exposures, collateral, and computes maintenance margin.","Sequencer matching cannot finalize trades without onchain verification, limiting MEV risk."]},{"header":"Unified Margin & Risk","bullets":["Single account collateral pool covers spot and perp positions across the portfolio.","Portfolio-level PnL and hedges recognized to lower effective margin and enable more leverage.","Idle deposits lent via onchain money markets; borrowers pay variable rates tied to utilization.","Maintenance margin calculated at account-level to support multi-leg strategies like basis trades."]},{"header":"NLP Vault Mechanics","bullets":["NLP vault accepts USDT0 from LPs and deploys capital into market-making and liquidation strategies.","LPs receive NLP positions that track vault share, earn variable APY from trading and liquidation fees.","NLP positions can be posted as collateral inside the unified margin system.","Vault capacity initially $1M then raised to $2M; individual deposit caps observed at $20K."]},{"header":"Private Alpha Traction","bullets":["$5B cumulative perp volume in ~3 weeks of private alpha; daily perp volume ~ $400M.","Open interest exceeded $40M with an active user base of ~1,000+ traders.","Reported TVL roughly $20M across deposits and NLP positions during private alpha.","Metrics position Nado among the highest-volume onchain CLOBs while still in private beta."]},{"header":"Strategic Positioning","bullets":["Targets active traders wanting CEX-like execution plus self-custody and portfolio margining.","Differentiates from AMM perps by offering explicit orderbook, multi-order types, and portfolio margin.","Built by ex-Kraken exchange engineers aiming for institutional-grade matching and execution.","Integrated money markets and NLP liquidity improve depth and reduce slippage for traders."]}],"projects":[{"project_id":13687,"project_name":"USDC"},{"project_id":15096,"project_name":"Kraken"},{"project_id":20564,"project_name":"USDT0"},{"project_id":26913,"project_name":"Ink"},{"project_id":41267,"project_name":"Nado"}],"images":[{"url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1765902512/veldt/bopxp0sa8vqqzxmuh9ql.jpg","title":"Unified Margin DEX Diagram","description":"The image is a diagram illustrating the concept of a Unified Margin DEX. The text at the top states \"Spot & Perps all in one DEX: Introducing Unified Margin.\" Below this, it explains that the entire portfolio (cash, spot, and unrealized PnL) becomes a single pool of collateral, enabling lower capital requirements for multi-leg strategies, cleaner risk management, and reduced liquidation risk. The image is on a black background, with white lines and text.
