The tweet also mentions an overview of the vault's design, NLP's role as a collateral asset, and its impact on liquidity and capital efficiency."}]},{"news_id":144236,"url":"https://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/speech/miran20251215a.htm","post_date":"2025-12-15T14:30:20.2+00:00","title":"Miran, The Inflation Outlook","source_name":"Federal Reserve","summary":"Federal Reserve Governor Stephen Miran delivers a speech outlining his inflation outlook, arguing that shelter inflation is a lagged aftereffect of earlier imbalances and should fall faster, that many imputed nonmarket price components (like portfolio management fees) create 'phantom' inflation, and that market-based core inflation ex-shelter is near the 2 percent target. He discusses goods inflation drivers (including tariffs) and concludes that policy should account for measurement distortions and monetary policy lags, favoring a quicker easing path to avoid unnecessary job losses.","bullets":["Shelter inflation reflects past supply–demand imbalances and, given rent dynamics and demographic shifts, should decline more quickly than headline measures suggest.","Nonmarket/imputed components (notably portfolio management fees) artificially inflate core PCE; removing them lowers measured underlying inflation materially.","Core nonhousing market-based services inflation is moderating and tied to labor market loosening; wages and labor-market signals point downward for service inflation.","Goods inflation rise is ambiguous—tariffs likely explain only a small portion; other factors (post-pandemic dynamics, supply-chain resilience, structural shifts) may matter.","Given measurement distortions and policy lags, Miran favors easing policy sooner to minimize employment costs while monitoring risks from shelter or persistent goods inflation."],"projects":[]},{"news_id":144198,"url":"https://www.theblock.co/post/382504/jpmorgan-launches-tokenized-money-market-fund-ethereum","post_date":"2025-12-15T12:07:01.073+00:00","title":"JPMorgan launches tokenized money-market fund on Ethereum: WSJ","source_name":"The Block","summary":"JPMorgan Asset Management launches My OnChain Net Yield Fund (MONY), a tokenized money-market fund on Ethereum seeded with $100 million of JPMorgan capital. The private vehicle issues digital tokens via the Kinexys platform, accepts USDC or cash, and targets qualified investors with a $1M minimum; it reflects growing institutional tokenization amid recent U.S. regulatory clarity.","bullets":["JPMorgan seeds MONY with $100M and will open subscriptions to qualified investors via Morgan Money.","Fund issues digital tokens on Ethereum through Kinexys Digital Assets and supports subscriptions/redemptions in cash or USDC.","MONY functions like a traditional money-market fund (short-term debt basket, daily dividends) but keeps assets onchain.","The launch follows industry moves (BlackRock, Goldman, BNY Mellon) and recent U.S. regulatory steps that encourage tokenization.","Target investors: individuals with ≥$5M in investable assets or institutions with ≥$25M; $1M minimum subscription."],"projects":[{"project_id":1819,"project_name":"BlackRock BUIDL"},{"project_id":4694,"project_name":"Ethereum"},{"project_id":13687,"project_name":"USDC"},{"project_id":29353,"project_name":"Galaxy"}]},{"news_id":144180,"url":"https://www.coindesk.com/policy/2025/12/15/uk-to-plans-to-start-regulating-cryptocurrency-in-2027","post_date":"2025-12-15T09:51:32.154+00:00","title":"UK to Plans to Start Regulating Cryptocurrency in 2027","source_name":"CoinDesk","summary":"The U.K. government will introduce legislation to Parliament extending existing financial regulation to crypto companies, with the regime scheduled to begin in October 2027. tools.name: searchContent
tools.description: Search and retrieve recent content from the Droyd knowledge base. Returns posts, news, tweets, YouTube videos, and developments, based on your filters. Use this as your primary tool for researching topics, finding recent information, and gathering context before responding to user queries.

search_mode.description: How to search the knowledge base. "recent" retrieves general recent relevant content filtered by ecosystem, category, and/or project. "semantic" searches for content matching a specific topic, question, or concept using semantic similarity.

semantic_query.description: A semantic query to search the knowledge base. This is used for more targeted research questions.

content_types.description: Types of content to search. Options: posts, news, developments, tweets, youtube. Leave empty to search all types.

limit.description: Maximum number of results to return. Default is 15.

days_back.description: Number of days to look back for content. Default is 7. Use 7 for recent news, 30 for medium term search, and max 90 for long term historical.

sort_by.description: How to sort results. "relevance" ranks by quality and engagement scores. "date" shows newest first. Default is "relevance".

minimum_relevance_score.description: Minimum relevance score threshold (0.0 to 1.0). Higher values filter out lower quality content. Default is 0.2.

ecosystem_ids.description: Filter by ecosystem IDs. Reference the ecosystem_ids <reference_ids> section of system prompts.

category_ids.description: Filter by category IDs. Reference the category_ids <reference_ids> section of system prompts.

project_ids.description: Filter by project IDs to get content about specific projects. Only use if project IDs are explicitly known from previous tool calls or hovered content. Max 20.

tools.name: readPosts
tools.description: Read the full text content of specific posts by their IDs. Use this tool when you need the complete article text, not just summaries. Accepts up to 10 post IDs at a time.

post_ids.description: Array of post IDs to read. Maximum 10 posts per request.

max_characters.description: Optional maximum characters for post text. If not specified, returns full text.

image_limit.description: Maximum number of images to include per post. Default is 3, max is 10.

tools.name: searchProjects
tools.description: Search for crypto projects/tokens in the database. Supports searching by project ID, project name, ticker symbol, contract address, or semantic similarity. Returns project details including market data, price analysis, and recent developments. PREFER using "project_id" search type when you have the project_id from previous tool results or context.

queries.description: Array of search queries. For project_id/name/symbol/address use single terms/IDs. For semantic use descriptive phrases.

search_type.description: Type of search: "project_id" for direct ID lookup (PREFERRED when available), "name" for project names, "symbol" for tickers, "address" for contract addresses, "semantic" for concept-based search.

limit.description: Maximum number of results per query. Default is 10.

tools.name: filterProjects
tools.description:
Screen and discover crypto assets using comprehensive filters. Translates natural language instructions into precise market filters covering:

- Market Data: market cap, price change, liquidity, volume
- On-Chain Metrics: traders, trader growth, holder count, buy/sell pressure
- Technical Indicators: momentum score, RSI, Bollinger Bands, MACD crossovers
- Social Signals: mentions, mindshare, social momentum

Returns a list of matching projects with market data, technicals, and recent developments.

instructions.description:
Natural language description of the filter criteria. Include details about:
- Market cap range (micro cap, small cap, mid cap, large cap, or specific values)
- Price action (pumping, dumping, oversold, overbought)
- Volume/liquidity requirements
- Technical conditions (bullish, bearish, MACD cross, RSI levels)
- Social signals (trending, gaining mindshare, under the radar)
- Chain preference (Solana, Ethereum, Base)
- Any specific thresholds or exclusions

Example: "Find trending micro-cap Solana tokens with high trader growth and good liquidity"

sort_by.description: Optional: Override the sort field. If not specified, will be inferred from instructions.

tools.name: getTrendReports
tools.description: Retrieve the last-generated trend report(s) for specified scope levels (global, specific ecosystem(s), and/or specific category(ies)). Each report is a high-level summary of trends, activities, events, and developments covering the past ~2 days at that scope level.

ecosystem_ids.description: Ecosystem IDs DIRECTLY mentioned by user. Common: 11943=Solana, 4694=Ethereum, 15071=Base, 813=Arbitrum, 1701=Bitcoin. ONLY include explicitly mentioned ecosystems. Leave empty to skip.

category_ids.description: Category IDs DIRECTLY mentioned by user. Common: 513=DeFi, 514=Derivatives, 547=RWAs, 517=AI/Agents, 520=Memecoins, 521=Stablecoins, 522=Ecosystems, 523=Rollups. ONLY include explicitly mentioned categories. Leave empty to skip.

include_global.description: Include global market report ONLY for broad general questions like "what's happening in crypto". Use this instead of listing many categories. Default false.

tools.name: getAgentTrades
tools.description: Retrieve recently closed trading positions from agents in the Droyd ecosystem. Returns detailed trade information including entry/exit prices, PnL, timing, and associated projects. Results are automatically ranked using time-decay page rank to surface the best recent trades.

scope.description: Scope of trades to retrieve. "all_platform" shows closed trades from all agents. "swarm_only" shows both open and closed trades from your swarm agents only.

hours_back.description: How many hours back to search for executed trades. Default is 168 (7 days). Use larger values like 720 for 30 days of history.

anyOf.description: Array of specific agent IDs to filter trades from. Leave empty/null to get trades from all agents. Note: Ignored when scope is "swarm_only".
Array of specific project IDs to filter trades by token/project. ONLY use when looking for successful trades of particular tokens. Leave null otherwise.

limit.description: Maximum number of trades to return. Default is 10.

tools.name: getWatchlist
tools.description: Retrieve intelligently ranked projects from agent watchlists. Returns projects sorted by momentum, mindshare, trader activity, and recent developments. Each project includes detailed market data, technical analysis, and the agents watching it with their investment thesis.

scope.description: Scope of watchlist to retrieve. "my_watchlist" shows only your watchlist. "swarm_watchlist" shows watchlists from your swarm agents. "combined" shows both.

limit.description: Maximum number of projects to return. Default is 15.

tools.name: compactTools
tools.description: Request compression of previous tool results to save context tokens and extend your analysis capability. Use this when you've extracted insights from large tool results and only need specific data preserved. The compression will be applied before your next step, allowing you to continue with more context budget available.

compact_jobs.description: Array of compression jobs to execute. Each job specifies which tool result to compact and how. Maximum 10 jobs per call.

tool_call_id.description: The EXACT toolCallId from the tool-result block you want to compact. Look in your conversation history for the "toolCallId" field in tool-result blocks. Format varies by provider (e.g., "Y9ZH8WbAvrUHCsDQ" for Google, "toolu_..." for Claude). DO NOT make up or use example IDs.

instructions.description: Summary focus instructions: Specify which items/projects/content to prioritize for detailed preservation. Tell the compactor what matters most and what insights to preserve. The compactor will create rich summaries maintaining identifiers (IDs, symbols, etc) and granular details for your priority items while condensing or removing less relevant data.

reason.description: Brief explanation of why you are compacting these results

content.text:
Method: pulled Droyd feed (last 30 days). Ranked projects by **reported YoY revenue growth** where available; where revenue wasn’t published I used **volume growth as a revenue proxy** (noted below).

![Artemis Weekly Fundamentals Dashboard](https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1768067691/veldt/tt1ow9iumm2jmrgju3pc.jpg)

1) **Figure** — **~$500M revenue run‑rate; ~50% YoY growth**  
- Catalysts: tokenized RWA product traction (HELOC / PRIME integrations), large marketplace volumes (~$3B) and institutional distribution; growing yield products that scale fee capture.  
- Why it grew: institutional onboarding + real‑world loan productization created recurring fee streams and rapid user/inflow expansion.

2) **Kalshi (prediction markets)** — **Volume +1,125% YoY (prediction‑market cohort)** → proxy for revenue spike  
- Catalysts: product-market fit for macro & sports event contracts, rapid distribution/partnerships with regulated venues, and compliance-driven institutional flows.  
- Why it grew: regulatory tolerance + mainstream distribution drove orderflow; fees scale directly with traded notional.

3) **Polymarket** — **$27.3B volume (+94% YoY)** → large revenue uplift implied  
- Catalysts: onboarding of mainstream bettors/traders, UX and fiat/stablecoin rails, and calendar-driven events (politics, sports) concentrating volume.  
- Why it grew: sticky user-engagement on high-attention events created outsized take rates vs prior periods.

![Prediction Market Spot Volume Growth](https://res.cloudinary.com/dgjriemfd/image/upload/v1767368994/veldt/ipw145rfkdcd4m3grnwh.jpg)

4) **Aerodrome Finance** — **DEX fees leader (~$2.1M/day); DEX volume +88%**  
- Catalysts: aggressive liquidity/product expansion on Base and multi‑chain aggregation, new economic engines (REV/AER) to capture fees and fund buybacks, and surfacing as a primary venue for large onchain flows.  
- Why it grew: onchain perp/spot demand concentrated on chains where Aerodrome captured orderflow + fee‑redistribution mechanics increased realized protocol revenue.

5) **Pendle** — **~$34M revenue (2025) with sharp 2025 uptake**  
- Catalysts: product-market fit for yield tokenization (PT/YT), multi‑chain TVL cycles, and active trading around fixed‑yield primitives plus Boros funding-rate products.  
- Why it grew: structurally higher fee-bearing activity (trading + yield structuring) and multiple incentive campaigns that amplified volume and revenue.

Notes: numbers and catalysts are taken directly from Droyd feed items (Artemis, PineAnalytics, Re7, prediction‑market coverage). Where only volume growth was reported I used it as a revenue proxy (prediction markets and DEX activity convert notional → fees at variable take rates).

content.text: Ranger's public ICO on MetaDAO concluded 2026-01-10: $86,398,012 committed from 8,761 contributors; raise capped at $8M, initial price $0.80 (FDV $20.5M); non-points holders to receive ~92.9% refunds. RNGR ticker and contract address published; tokens claimable via MetaDAO.

UNIfication executed onchain Dec 27, 2025: Uniswap burned 100,000,000 UNI from the treasury, Labs frontend fees set to zero, protocol fees enabled for select v2/v3 pools, and Unichain sequencer fees will flow to UNI burn (net OP & L1 data costs).

Lighter distributed 250M LIT (25% of 1B) at TGE; token allocation: 50% ecosystem, 26% team, 24% investors. Team/investor vesting: one-year cliff then three-year linear. ~ $31.9M withdrawn post-launch (Ethereum $23.0M, Arbitrum $8.9M).

Wyoming publicly issued the Frontier Stable Token (FRNT) on 2026-01-07; FRNT is native on Solana and bridged to Ethereum, Arbitrum, Base, Optimism, Polygon, and Avalanche. Franklin Templeton will manage reserves; Fiduciary Trust Company International is custodian; initially purchasable on Kraken.

INX sale policy changed Jan 5: per-wallet caps removed; allocation switched to bottom-up "water-filling"; Patron NFT priority retained. Initial sale raised roughly $600k in the first three days against a $5M target from the 5% allocation.
JupUSD launched 2026-01-05; Earn and Borrow vaults went live with deep JupUSD integrations and the stablecoin gathered $17.6M of deposits in its first week.

content.title: Artemis: Stablecoin volume $33T in 2025
content.summary: Artemis data, featured in Bloomberg, shows stablecoin transaction volume reached $33 trillion in 2025 (+72% YoY). USDC accounted for $18.3T, USDT $13.3T. Q4 alone was $11T. Bloomberg projects volumes could reach $56T by 2030.

bullets: Artemis data featured in Bloomberg documenting record stablecoin flows in 2025.
Total stablecoin transactions: $33T in 2025, a 72% year‑over‑year increase.
USDC: $18.3T in transactions; USDT: $13.3T in transactions.
Q4 2025 alone generated $11T, an all‑time quarterly high.
Bloomberg cites a projection of ~$56T in stablecoin transactions by 2030.

images.title: Bloomberg Article on Record Stablecoin Transaction Volume
images.description: A screenshot of a Bloomberg Technology news article with the headline 'Stablecoin Transactions Rose to Record $33 Trillion, Led by USDC'. The article features a photograph of a laptop screen displaying the Circle website, which describes USDC as 'Fully backed digital dollars' and lists partners including Worldpay, MoneyGram, Wintermute, and Visa. According to the associated data from Artemis, the $33 trillion volume was reached in 2025, marking a 72% year-over-year increase. The breakdown shows USDC leading with $18.3 trillion in volume, followed by USDT with $13.3 trillion. The report also notes that Q4 2025 alone saw $11 trillion in transactions and projects that volumes could reach $56 trillion by 2030.

content.title: Ethereum must pass the walkaway test
content.summary: Vitalik argues Ethereum must be 'walkaway-safe': the base layer should allow users to keep meaningful functionality without ongoing vendor updates. He lists concrete goals: full quantum-resistance, ZK-EVM + PeerDAS scalability, durable state architecture (partial statelessness & expiry), full account abstraction, DoS‑resistant gas schedule, robust long-term PoS economics, and censorship‑resistant block building. He urges incremental yearly progress toward ossification while preserving optional future change.

bullets: Ethereum should permit users to 'walk away' and retain usable, trustless applications without vendor dependence.
Protocol must be able to 'ossify'—not stop innovation, but ensure core value doesn't rely on future non-enshrined features.
Full quantum-resistance: aim for protocol cryptographic safety for a century.
Scalability via ZK‑EVM validation and data sampling (PeerDAS); future scaling as parameter changes.
State longevity: partial statelessness, state expiry, and storage/tree future-proofing for decades.
Full account abstraction: remove ECDSA enshrinement for general-purpose accounts.
Gas schedule hardened against DoS in both execution and ZK proving.
PoS economic model and block-building must remain decentralized and censorship-resistant long-term.

content.title: Global AI compute doubling every 7 months
content.summary: Epoch AI reports global AI compute is doubling roughly every 7 months (≈3.3x/year since 2022, 90% CI: 2.7–4.1x). Their quarter-by-quarter chip-sales estimates (H100-equivalents) show Nvidia supplying >60% of new capacity; Google TPUs and AWS Trainium account for most of the remainder. Epoch links to an AI Chip Sales hub with methodology, model-equivalence (H100e) conversions, and 90% confidence intervals.

bullets: Epoch estimates global AI compute doubles every 7 months (3.3x/year; 90% CI: 2.7–4.1x).
Figures are expressed as H100-equivalent compute to standardize chip performance.
Estimates derive from quarterly chip-sales tracking across major designers since 2022.
NVIDIA constitutes over 60% of new AI compute capacity in their estimates.
Google TPUs and Amazon Trainium/Inferentia supply most of the remaining capacity.
Epoch projects B300/B200 growth and rising contributions from TPU v7 and Trainium2.
Epoch links to an 'AI Chip Sales' hub with methodology, per-vendor models, and CI intervals.
Estimates use earnings, disclosures, data-center tracking; uncertainty varies by vendor.

images.title: Global AI Compute Capacity Growth and Hardware Distribution (2022-2025)
images.description: A stacked bar chart from Epoch AI showing the exponential growth of global AI computing capacity from Q1 2022 to a projected Q1 2025. The capacity is measured in H100-equivalent (H100e) units, with the total capacity projected to reach approximately 15 million units by early 2025. The chart highlights that AI compute is doubling every 7 months, which is a 3.3x annual growth rate (90% CI: 2.7-4.1x). Nvidia is the dominant supplier, representing over 60% of the capacity with its H100/H200, B200, and B300 chips. Other major contributors include Google (TPU v5e, v6e, v7), Amazon (Trainium1/2 and Inferentia), AMD (MI300X), and Huawei (Ascend 910B/C). The visualization clearly shows the rapid acceleration of hardware deployment starting in 2024.

images.title: AI Chip Sales and Compute Capacity Share 2024-2025
images.description: A stacked bar chart titled 'AI Chip Sales' illustrating the quarterly share of compute capacity from 2024 Q1 to 2025 Q3. The chart categorizes sales by manufacturer and specific chip models. Nvidia is the dominant leader, consistently capturing over 60% of the market share. Within Nvidia's segment, there is a clear transition from H100/H200 models to B200 (appearing in 2024 Q4) and B300 (appearing in 2025 Q2). Google follows with a significant share (approx. 10-15%) through its TPU line, including TPU v5e, v6e, and v7. Amazon's share is represented by Trainium1/Inferentia and the newer Trainium2, which grows in prominence starting in 2024 Q4. AMD's contribution is primarily the MI300X, while Huawei's share includes the Ascend 910B and 910C models. The data, sourced from Epoch AI, highlights the rapid evolution and competitive landscape of AI hardware infrastructure.

content.summary: Messari reports $495M raised across 16 deals this week, highlights @Metaplanet's $451M BTC purchase and notes an acquisition by @FireblocksHQ. Short weekly venture roundup flagging large corporate BTC buy and M&A activity.

bullets: $495M raised across 16 venture deals reported this week.
Notable corporate treasury move: @Metaplanet purchased $451M in BTC (callout in tweet).
M&A activity: the tweet notes an acquisition involving @FireblocksHQ (no target named).

The largest deal was Rain, which raised $250M with investors including Iconiq Capital, Dragonfly, and Galaxy Ventures. The second largest was Babylon, raising $15M from a16z crypto. content.title: US Treasury Faces Structural Funding Squeeze
content.summary: Delphi Digital argues the US Treasury market faces structural fragility: weakening foreign demand, BOJ-driven Japanese disinterest, and heavy reliance on ~$2T of hedge-fund basis trades to absorb issuance. Monthly rollovers (~$150B bills, ~$300B coupon) and nearly $10T to refinance heighten reliance on the Fed's Standing Repo Facility as a liquidity backstop. Chart shows sharp growth in T-bills versus notes, bonds, and TIPS through Dec 2025.

bullets: Foreign demand for Treasuries is weakening; reliance on leveraged flows has increased.
BOJ normalization raises Japanese yields, reducing life insurers' and pension funds' US allocations.
Hedge funds' ~$2T basis trade underpins the long end of the curve.
Rollover pressure: ~ $150B in T‑bills and ~$300B in coupon debt mature monthly; nearly $10T to refinance next 12 months.
Fed's Standing Repo Facility functions as an open liquidity valve; permanence or regulatory relief could monetize Treasury debt.

images.title: US Treasury Debt Growth by Instrument Type (2023-2025)
images.description: A line chart from Delphi Digital illustrating the normalized growth of US debt held by the public from May 2023 to December 2025. The chart tracks four specific debt instruments: T-bills (orange), Notes (white), Bonds (blue), and TIPS (green), all normalized to a baseline as of May 31, 2023. The data shows a significant divergence in issuance: T-bills have experienced the sharpest increase, reaching a normalized value of 2.731M by December 2025. Notes follow with a steady climb to 1.780M. Bonds show more moderate growth, ending at 1.055M, while TIPS remain the most stable, ending at 0.197M. This trend indicates a heavy reliance on short-term debt (T-bills) to fund the US government, which the chart titles as a 'Structural Funding Squeeze'. The chart is sourced from Bloomberg data as of December 8th, 2025.

content.title: Why PeerDAS + ZK‑EVMs Reshape Ethereum
content.summary: Vitalik argues that PeerDAS (data-availability sampling live on mainnet) combined with production-quality ZK‑EVM performance (safety remaining) converts Ethereum into a decentralized, consensus-driven, high-bandwidth network—solving the prior bandwidth/consensus tradeoff. He gives a multi-year rollout: 2026 gas-limit increases and first ZK‑EVM nodes, 2026–28 repricings and state/execution changes, 2027–30 ZK‑EVMs driving larger gas increases. He also highlights distributed block building and reducing centralized builder authority.

bullets: PeerDAS is live on mainnet; ZK‑EVMs are production-quality in performance, with safety work remaining.
Combination yields decentralized consensus plus high bandwidth—claims the trilemma effectively solved in practice.
Timeline: 2026 gas-limit increases and first ZK‑EVM node opportunities; 2026–28 repricings and state changes.
2027–30: ZK‑EVMs could become primary validation method, enabling larger gas limits.
Advocates distributed block building (in-protocol or marketplace) to reduce centralized builder authority and improve fairness.

Capital rotated off Ethereum and Hyperliquid into Arbitrum, Ink, and Base via bridges.

content.title: Stablecoins: Rails Not Brands
content.summary: Threaded analysis arguing stablecoins are payment rails, not branding exercises. Artemis details operational advantages (lower settlement costs, instant 24/7 settlement, cross-border reach), corporate strategies (Stripe prefers integration; PayPal, Klarna, Cash App take different approaches), market structure (USDT ~60%, USDC ~26% as of Dec 2025; $310B supply), and supply projections to 2030. Key takeaway: integration and distribution matter far more than issuing a token.

bullets: Stablecoins change how money moves, not what money is; value comes from reducing settlement friction.
Issuing a stablecoin is not a guaranteed win — integration and distribution drive durable value.
A few widely accepted stablecoins suffice; thousands of branded tokens would create fragmentation and user friction.
Lower settlement costs: on-chain settlement can reduce card interchange (~1–3%) to cents for eligible flows.
Instant, 24/7 settlement removes banking cutoffs and speeds payouts for high-frequency merchants.
Cross-border reach: stablecoins bypass bilateral bank relationships; FX conversion remains an optional step for merchants.
Stripe: neutral on issuance, enables payouts/acceptance and internalized plumbing via Bridge Network acquisition.
PayPal (PYUSD): defensive play leveraging existing wallets and distribution; flow is the value, not float.
Klarna, Cash App: using stablecoins to compress settlement costs or embed rails into product UX.
As of Dec 2025 USDT ~60% and USDC ~26% of stablecoin supply; total supply ~$310B.
At 40% annual growth, supply could reach ~$1.6T by 2030; incumbents likely lose share but a small set will dominate.
Issuance-only players risk irrelevance unless they control flows, wallets, or distribution.

content.text: Coinbase launches 24/5 U.S. stock and ETF trading inside the Coinbase app, available beginning Dec 17, 2025 with unified account and portfolio view.

Validators voted to recognize the Assistance Fund HYPE as permanently burned: 19 yes, 2 no. No onchain transfer required; tokens remain in an irretrievable system address and the vote creates binding social consensus to never authorize upgrades accessing it.
Invesco and Galaxy launched the Invesco Galaxy Solana ETF (QSOL) on 2025-12-15, providing a regulated ETP/ETF product that tracks SOL with prospectus and product page published.

content.title: Crypto Market Structure: Senate Markup Expectations
content.summary: Alex Thorn summarizes Galaxy Research’s take on the Senate Banking Committee markup scheduled for Jan 15 on the Responsible Financial Innovation Act. He outlines key players (Sen. Tim Scott, Sen. Boozman, Sen. Booker), core negotiation flashpoints (DeFi AML classification, stablecoin yield sharing, protections for non‑custodial developers, SEC authority), and stakes: bipartisan committee support is critical for floor passage; passage would materially clarify token classification and regulator jurisdictions, while failure mainly risks market sentiment and delays.

bullets: Senate Banking Committee to markup the Responsible Financial Innovation Act on Jan 15; similar activity rumored in Senate Agriculture.
Private bipartisan talks and a White House push intensified negotiations this week.
Key Senators named: Tim Scott (chairman), John Boozman (Agriculture), and Sen. Booker (Democratic negotiator with wavering support).
Classification of DeFi under AML rules is the most consequential outstanding issue.
Dispute over stablecoin reserve yield sharing and whether to ban issuers sharing yield with holders.
Questions on exemptions for non‑custodial developers from AML/money transmitter rules and SEC authority over token issuance.
Other items: Treasury sanction powers and conflict‑of‑interest rules for officials.
A strong bipartisan committee vote (all Republicans plus 2–4 Democrats) greatly raises floor passage odds.
If advanced bipartisan, final vote could mirror GENIUS Act dynamics and produce decisive margins.
Failure to advance reduces near‑term legislative odds; industry has partial protections via administrative pivots already.

content.title: Wrench attacks vs. crypto user growth
content.summary: Haseeb analyzed Jameson Lopp's 'wrench attacks' dataset and created visualizations. Absolute attacks and severity have increased; a simple regression vs. market cap yields R²=0.45. Normalizing by Coinbase MAUs and market cap shows per-user/per-dollar risk fell since 2015, though recent per-user upticks align with 2021 levels. Western Europe and APAC show the largest increases. Thread includes interactive visualizations, code link, and practical personal-security recommendations.

bullets: Analysis uses Jameson Lopp's curated wrench-attacks database of reported violent crypto thefts.
Absolute number of attacks rose substantially from 2017 onward, peaking sharply in 2024–2025.
Severity shifted toward more Serious/Severe incidents; Fatal incidents appear from 2017 onward.
Simple regression of violence vs. total crypto market cap gives R² ≈ 0.45 (market cap explains ~45% of variance).
Higher market value correlates with more attacks in absolute terms, per the white-line vs bars visualization.
Normalized metrics: attacks per Coinbase MAU and attacks per $B market cap show much higher rates in 2015 and 2018.
Per-user risk fell as user base grew (Coinbase MAUs from ~2M to ~120M), though there's a recent moderate uptick near 2021 levels.
Western Europe and APAC show the largest increases in violence; North America remains relatively safer in this dataset.
Practical advice: avoid signaling wealth, use PO boxes/hot wallets, delete personal data, consider security guards if high-risk.

images.title: Normalized Crypto Physical Attack Rates (2014-2025)
images.description: A line chart titled 'Normalized Attack Rates Over Time' that compares two metrics from 2014 to 2025: 'Attacks per million Coinbase MAUs' (blue line) and 'Attacks per $B market cap' (green line). The chart shows a significant peak for both metrics in 2015, with attacks per million users reaching approximately 2.5 and attacks per $B market cap reaching 1.0. Following 2015, both rates dropped sharply. The attacks per $B market cap have remained near zero since 2017, indicating that attacks are not scaling linearly with market valuation. The attacks per million Coinbase users stabilized between 0.3 and 0.6 from 2019 to 2024, with a slight upward trend projected for 2025. This data suggests that while absolute numbers of attacks might be increasing, the relative risk per user and per dollar of market value has significantly decreased since the early years of the crypto industry.

images.title: Severity Breakdown of Physical Crypto Attacks 2014-2025
images.description: A data dashboard visualizing the severity of physical attacks on cryptocurrency users, categorized into five levels. The top section provides a summary of 269 total incidents: Minor (23 incidents, 9%), Moderate (39 incidents, 14%), Serious (137 incidents, 51%), Severe (57 incidents, 21%), and Fatal (13 incidents, 5%). Definitions for each level are provided, ranging from 'Theft without confrontation' for Minor to 'Victim was killed' for Fatal. The bottom section features a stacked bar chart showing the percentage breakdown of these severity levels by year from 2014 to 2025. The data reveals a shift in attack composition: 2014 was 100% 'Minor' attacks, whereas from 2018 onwards, 'Serious' (orange) and 'Severe' (red) attacks dominate the distribution. 'Serious' attacks, involving armed robbery or home invasion, consistently represent the largest portion of incidents in the latter half of the decade. 'Fatal' incidents (purple) are visible in the breakdown for most years starting from 2017.

content.title: Solana Alpenglow: Votor & Rotor explained
content.summary: Delphi Digital summarizes Solana's Alpenglow consensus overhaul: two components — Votor (off-chain vote aggregation with fast/slow finalization thresholds) and Rotor (stake-weighted relay propagation). Claims: theoretical finality of 100–150ms (from 12.8s) and simulated block propagation as low as 18ms. Initial activation expected early–mid 2026.

bullets: Alpenglow replaces Tower BFT and PoH to target sub-second finality for Solana.
Votor replaces incremental rounds with offchain vote aggregation, finalizing in one or two confirmation rounds.
Fast finalization: ≥80% stake approval in first round finalizes immediately.
Slow finalization: first-round 60–80% needs second round >60% to finalize; both paths run concurrently.
Rotor restructures block propagation with stake-weighted relay paths; simulation shows propagation as low as 18ms.
Theoretical finality reduced to ~100–150 ms (≈100x faster than 12.8s baseline).
Rotor prioritizes high-stake, high-bandwidth validators as relays for efficient propagation.
Upgrade rollout expected gradually with initial activation anticipated early to mid 2026.
Tweet includes a technical diagram mapping leader, relay, notarization, and final vote timing.

images.title: Alpenglow Block Life Cycle Diagram
images.description: A technical diagram illustrating the 'Full Common Case Life Cycle of a Block in Alpenglow,' a proposed consensus overhaul for the Solana blockchain. The diagram uses a horizontal timeline format with four distinct tracks: 'Leader sends' (purple arrow), 'Relays send' (green arrow), 'Notar. votes' (pink arrows), and 'Final. votes' (blue arrow). The process begins with the leader and relays sending data. The first phase of notarization votes leads to the 'Notarization' milestone. A subsequent, shorter phase of notarization votes leads to 'Fast-finalization.' Concurrently, a longer 'Final. votes' process culminates in the 'Slow-finalization' milestone. This visualization demonstrates the parallel nature of block propagation and the tiered finality system (Fast vs. Slow) introduced by the Alpenglow architecture, which utilizes components like Votor for vote aggregation and Rotor for relay propagation.

content.title: EIP-7702 2025 usage trends
content.summary: Kofi (BundleBear) summarizes EIP-7702 adoption in 2025: 6.6M wallets currently hold active 7702 authorizations (40% tied to hacker contracts). Excluding hackers, Bitget leads with ~605k authorizations; Metamask and Ambire follow. 1.2M non-hacker 7702 accounts transacted in December (uptrend). Monthly ERC-4337 UserOps from 7702 accounts hit an ATH of 926k in December, driven by Coinbase Wallet → Base App upgrades. Link to the full BundleBear write-up included.

bullets: Over 6.6M wallets have an active EIP-7702 authorization right now.
40% of those active authorizations point to hacker contracts (used after key compromise).
Excluding hacker contracts, Bitget leads with ~605k authorized accounts; MetaMask and Ambire follow.
1.2M non-hacker EIP-7702 accounts transacted in December; monthly activity trended up through 2025.
EIP-7702 accounts made a December ATH of 926k ERC-4337 UserOps, driven by Coinbase Wallet → Base upgrades.

content.title: US leads AI frontier; China trails by 7 months
content.summary: Epoch AI reports that since 2023 the leading AI frontier models have been US-origin, with Chinese models trailing by an average of seven months. A step-chart (ECI index, 2023–early 2026) shows US models (GPT-4, o1-mini, o1, GPT-5, Gemini 3 Pro Preview) consistently scoring higher than Chinese models (Baichuan2-13B, Qwen-14B, Yi-34B, DeepSeek-V2, Qwen2.5-72B, DeepSeek-R1, Qwen3 Max). The gap remains relatively stable over time.

bullets: Epoch AI visualizes ECI from 2023 to early 2026 showing a persistent US lead.
Measured gap: Chinese models trail the US frontier by ~7 months on average.
US frontier models annotated: GPT-4, o1-mini, o1, GPT-5, Gemini 3 Pro Preview.
Chinese models shown: Baichuan2-13B, Qwen-14B, Yi-34B, DeepSeek-V2, Qwen2.5-72B, DeepSeek-R1, Qwen3 Max.

images.title: US vs China AI Model Performance Lag Comparison
images.description: A step chart from Epoch AI titled 'Chinese AI models have lagged the US frontier by 7 months on average since 2023'. The chart plots the Epoch Capability Index (ECI) on the y-axis against a timeline from 2023 to early 2026 on the x-axis. Two distinct lines are shown: a blue line for United States models and a red line for Chinese models. The US line begins with GPT-4 (March 2023) at an ECI of approximately 126 and progresses through o1-mini, o1, GPT-5, and Gemini 3 Pro Preview, ending above 150. The Chinese line starts with Baichuan2-13B in late 2023 at an ECI of 100 and advances through Qwen-14B, Yi-34B (chat), DeepSeek-V2 (MoE-236B), Qwen2.5-72B, DeepSeek-R1, and Qwen3 Max, ending near 145. The visualization demonstrates that while both regions are rapidly improving, Chinese models consistently reach capability milestones roughly 7 months after their US counterparts.

Stani frames the outcome as a relief for Aave and DeFi, calling it a new era for developers and stating “DeFi will win.” An image of the SEC letter is attached.

Attached image is an SEC letter dated August 12, 2025, referencing Release No. 5310.
Founder emphasizes the effort required by the team and himself to protect Aave and DeFi.
Frames conclusion as enabling a 'new era' for developers to build fintech onchain.
Expresses positive confidence: 'DeFi will win.'

content.title: Tokenised TradFi: 2025–2026 On‑Chain Breakthroughs
content.summary: 2025: institutional RWA tokenisation breakout. Major banks and asset managers moved from pilots to production, issuing and settling tokenised bonds, deposits and money-market funds on public and permissioned chains. Key live products include BlackRock BUIDL, J.P. Morgan’s MONY, Franklin Templeton’s BENJI and Circle-linked USYC. Canton Network enabled 24/7 U.S. Treasury financing; UBS and others completed on-chain fund redemptions and tokenised bond issuances. Tokenisation delivers 24/7 liquidity, instant settlement, fractional access, automated reporting and faster redemptions, accelerating institutional use-cases for yield-bearing RWAs. Market note: BTC higher lows but volatile amid DOJ/Fed headlines; markets need more conviction to close gap to equities.

bullets: OCBC: first full production corporate bond tokenisation under MAS (Jan 2025).
Wall Street consortium on Canton enabled 24/7 on-chain U.S. Treasury financing (Aug 2025).
Societe Generale issued a U.S. digital bond on Canton (Nov 2025).
UBS executed first on-chain redemption of a tokenised money market fund (Nov 2025).
J.P. Morgan launched MONY, the first tokenised MMF on public Ethereum (Dec 2025).
MMFs emerged as a breakout institutional use-case bridging TradFi yield with blockchain settlement.
BlackRock BUIDL, Franklin Templeton BENJI, J.P. Morgan MONY and Circle-linked USYC are live and scaling.
Tokenised MMFs function as on-chain cash equivalents with instant settlement and automated redemptions.
Fractional ownership lowers capital barriers and enables seamless on-chain cash management for institutions.
Liquidity: tokenised assets trade 24/7 versus constrained legacy hours.
Settlement: on-chain instant settlement replaces T+1 or T+2 processes.
Redemption/Access: automated redemptions and fractional ownership improve access and speed.
Reporting/Compliance: smart contracts enable automated reporting and compliance viewing keys.
Canton Network used for regulated, interoperable, compliant institutional workflows and atomic settlement.
Chainlink infrastructure supported UBS’s on-chain redemption flows.
Platforms and custodians (Broadridge, Kinexys, Ant International, BNY Mellon integrations) enable production-grade issuance.
Major market participants (BlackRock, J.P. Morgan, SocGen, UBS, BNY Mellon, Lloyds, Citadel) drove live transactions.
Crypto markets remain volatile; BTC forming higher lows but facing resistance near $94.7k.
Short-term volatility amplified by DOJ subpoenas to the Federal Reserve and potential Powell indictment headlines.
Investor sentiment fragile; on-chain institutional adoption provides a constructive fundamental narrative for DeFi yield.

images.title: Benefits of Tokenization vs. Legacy Systems Comparison
images.description: A comparison table titled 'Benefits of Tokenisation vs. legacy systems (Across Asset Classes)' by Re7Capital. The table evaluates five key features: Liquidity, Settlement, Redemption, Access, and Reporting. For Liquidity, legacy systems have constrained trading hours while tokenized systems offer 24/7 availability. Settlement in legacy systems takes T+1 or T+2 days, whereas tokenized systems provide instant settlement at blockchain speed. Redemption is described as slow for legacy and instant for tokenized systems. Access in legacy systems requires high capital, but tokenization enables low capital requirements through fractional ownership. Finally, reporting is manual in legacy systems and automated via smart contracts in tokenized systems.

images.title: Money Market Fund Tokenisation Flowchart
images.description: A flowchart detailing the lifecycle of a tokenized money market fund. The process begins with the underlying Asset (fund shares), which are digitized into blockchain-based tokens. These tokens reside on a blockchain, which can be either permissioned or permissionless. A Smart Contract acts as the central logic hub, interacting with on-chain Trades and Settlement processes. Below the blockchain layer, a Compliance Viewing Keys section includes Wallets and Deposit/Redemption mechanisms. The diagram specifies that trades occur on the blockchain within regulated digital platforms and are settled directly to respective on-chain wallets. The flowchart illustrates the transition from traditional fund shares to a digitized, smart-contract-managed ecosystem for improved liquidity and settlement efficiency.

content.title: Privacy Trends for 2026
content.summary: Privacy is now core infrastructure. Privacy-centric assets outperformed in 2025 (Zcash +820%, Monero +130%) while BTC/ETH fell. Regulatory shifts (U.S. Treasury Tornado Cash reversal), Ethereum Foundation privacy unit, and Paxos–Aleo private stablecoin signal institutional acceptance. ZK proofs and zkVMs reached practical performance; MPC and TEEs saw targeted adoption; FHE remains too slow. Zcash experienced a governance-driven developer exodus in late 2025, exposing funding and governance fragilities. Three 2026 scenarios range from conservative enterprise-only adoption to accelerated mainstream privacy on public rails. Key investor considerations: composable privacy plus compliance, governance risk, and interoperability trade-offs.

bullets: Privacy shifted from niche feature to foundational infrastructure by early 2026.
Demand rose after 2025 performance of privacy assets and regulatory softening.
Composability plus compliance is now the dominant adoption model for institutions.
Zcash rallied ~820% in 2025; Monero rose ~130% versus BTC/ETH declines.
Shielded pool usage and shielded-asset pilots reached all-time activity highs.
Regulatory reversals reduced uncertainty, prompting TradFi pilots and funds.
zk-SNARKs, zkVMs, and zk-rollups moved from research to production-ready tooling.
MPC matured for custody and private analytics; latency constrains open-chain logic.
FHE is feasible in demos but impractical for general on-chain use in 2026.
TEEs provide high performance but retain hardware trust and supply-chain risks.
Tokenized assets and confidential payments enable private settlements with selective disclosure.
Custodians use MPC and shielded contracts to reconcile privacy with auditability.
Trade finance and invoicing are early, high-fit applications for private ledgers.
Zcash developer exodus exposed governance, funding, and talent concentration risks.
Privacy-as-a-moat can create lock-in but may hinder cross-chain interoperability.
Regulators accept privacy paired with oversight; opaque systems risk deplatforming.

images.title: Comparison of Privacy Enhancing Technologies: MPC vs TEE vs FHE
images.description:
A comparison table titled 'PETs TODAY' evaluating three Privacy Enhancing Technologies (PETs): Multi-Party Computation (MPC), Trusted Execution Environments (TEE), and Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE). 

For MPC, the pros include shared state, sharded secrets, and permissionless delegated compute; the cons are trust assumptions across a non-colluding set of nodes, slowness for multi-operations, and latency/low I/O due to communication delays with many nodes. 

For TEE, the pros include being highly performant, highly expressive, having a mature developer experience (DevEx), multiple viable types, and the ability to run in cloud/data centers with abstraction; the cons are trust assumptions across an opaque hardware supply chain and infrastructure operators, and being memory bound. 

For FHE, the pros include being collusion resistant (especially without decryption) and having schemes that can potentially be made post-quantum secure; the cons are being slow for single operations, computationally expensive, volatile due to noise, requiring MPC trust for decryption via a network key, and having many moving parts (schemes, parameters, hardware) for developers.

content.title: Decentralized AI training: 600,000x growth
content.summary: Epoch AI presents data and techniques showing decentralized training runs grew ~600,000x since 2021 (implied 20x/year trend). The thread summarizes low-bandwidth/data- and model-parallel methods (DiLoCo, PowerSGD, pipeline parallelism, online filtering), cites examples (SWARM, INTELLECT, Covenant 72B), and argues compute aggregation (folding@home, Bitcoin analogies) is the primary bottleneck.

bullets: Epoch charts indicate ~600,000x increase in decentralized training compute since 2021.
Dotted trend line implies ~20x/year growth (80% CI: 10x–30x/year).
Data points highlight projects like DeDLOC/sahajBERT-XL, SWARM, INTELLECT-1, Protocol Models.
Decentralized data parallelism: DiLoCo (synchronize after steps), streaming DiLoCo, gradient compression (PowerSGD, DeMo).
Decentralized model parallelism: pipeline-style layer splitting and activation compression for lower bandwidth.
Decentralized RL: overlap trace generation with training and filter traces without signal (online advantage filtering).
Main constraint is amassing sustained compute across many machines in low-bandwidth settings.
Epoch compares effective throughput to folding@home and Bitcoin-capex, showing much larger feasible networks.
Examples cited include INTELLECT variants, Covenant 72B, and SWARM as existing decentralized efforts.

images.title: Decentralized AI Training Network Size Comparison
images.description: This infographic compares the effective throughput (FLOP/s) of various decentralized AI training networks. The chart presents a horizontal bar graph with the following networks and their corresponding throughput: Pluralis (8e14), Prime Intellect (1e16), Psyche (2e16), Templar (9e16), folding@home (2.4e18), and Bitcoin CapEx equivalent (3e20). The x-axis represents effective throughput in FLOP/s, ranging from 10^15 to 10^20. The text at the bottom provides context, stating that the effective throughput accounts for downtime and MFU (Mean Fractional Utilization). It also mentions that the Bitcoin comparison assumes current Bitcoin infrastructure capex ($30bn) translates to AI computing infrastructure at $36bn/GW, 1,400 peak GFLOP/s/Watt, and 30% MFU. The image's title states that today's largest decentralized AI training networks are 30-3,000x smaller than comparable decentralized projects.

images.title: Decentralized Training Compute Growth
images.description: This chart illustrates the growth of decentralized training runs over the internet, highlighting a 600,000x increase since 2021. The y-axis represents training compute in FLOP (floating-point operations per second) on a logarithmic scale from 10^18 to 10^26. The x-axis spans from 2021 to 2026. Data points are color-coded: teal for top 1 centralized, pink for top 3 decentralized, and open pink circles for other decentralized. The chart includes a dotted pink trend line indicating a 20x/year growth rate with an 80% confidence interval of 10x-30x/year. Key data points are labeled, including DeDLOC/sahajBERT-XL in 2021, SWARM in 2023, INTELLECT-1- in 2024, and Protocol Models in 2025. The chart suggests a significant shift towards decentralized training.

content.title: Alpenglow: 150ms finality, 50-node test
content.summary: Anza reports Alpenglow reduces finality to ~150 milliseconds, improves safety, and offers ways to mitigate slot laggers. They say a 50-node global cluster ran under load for months with almost no issues.

bullets: Alpenglow reduces finality to ~150 milliseconds, per the tweet.
Claims increased safety and new approaches to defeat slot laggers.
Anza reports a 50-node global cluster ran under load for months.
Test cluster reportedly experienced 'almost no issues' during the run.

Bitcoin trading ~$87.5k with rising dominance; stablecoin supply stalled at $305B and lending yields below risk-free, pressuring leverage. Base stands out for stablecoin transfer volume. Capital consolidating into Bitcoin, large caps with clear narratives, and gold hedges.
Base case next 1–3 months: range-bound BTC-led consolidation; fundamentals trump momentum.
BTC ~ $87.5k; dominance ~59.5%, ETH dominance ~12.1%; short-term BTC range $85k–$94k.

content.title: Artemis: Stablecoins as Business Settlement Rail
content.summary: Artemis presents an empirical analysis of USDC and USDT EOA-to-EOA transfers on Ethereum (Aug 2024–Aug 2025). After filtering smart-contract noise, findings: P2P transactions are 67% of counts but only 24% of volume; business-related transfers (B2B + Internal B) are <8% of transactions yet >33% of volume. Weekday-dominant cadence, high concentration (top 1,000 senders ≈84% volume), and larger per-transaction values for businesses indicate stablecoins are emerging as a settlement layer for corporate payments, treasury routing, cross-border payouts and supplier payments. Analysis uses Artemis EOA labeling; results exclude proprietary payments partner data.

bullets: Study covers all USDC and USDT transfers on Ethereum from Aug 2024–Aug 2025, focusing on EOA→EOA transfers as payments.
Artemis labeling classifies wallets (individual vs institution) and excludes smart-contract interactions, mints/burns, and bridge events.
Filtering removes automated DeFi/small-value bot activity to estimate economically meaningful payment flows.
P2P = 67% of EOA→EOA transactions but only ~24% of volume; many P2P are low-value, likely bots or automated.
Business-related transfers (B2B + Internal B) <8% of transactions yet contribute >33% of total volume.
Top 1,000 sender wallets account for ~84% of volume, showing heavy institutional concentration.
Weekday-heavy activity with sharp weekend drops, matching corporate payment cycles rather than retail trading.
Transaction-value CDFs show business categories have much higher values than P2P; very small transfers (<$0.1) flagged as suspicious.
Volume increased materially from Aug 2024 to Aug 2025, with rising weekly adoption across categories.
Stablecoins function increasingly as business settlement infrastructure for treasury routing, supplier payouts, and cross-border settlement.
Programmability and global interoperability make stablecoins attractive for institutional liquidity management.
Findings inform regulators, payments providers, and financial institutions assessing digital settlement futures.

content.title: Yield: Sector Update — Pendle & Merkl
content.summary: Stablecoin benchmark yields fell to ~3.8%. The vaults.fyi 30-day "blue chip" stablecoin benchmark dropped to ~3.8%, near the 1-month U.S. T-bill at 3.7%; Aave USDC/USDT yields sit below risk-free. Active farmers still find >10% APY opportunities (incentive-driven). Pendle tokenizes principal and yield, peaking at $12.9B TVL across 8 chains in 2025 and generating $34M revenue for the year. Pendle trading volume peaked near $12B in Sept 2025 and added Boros perpetual funding trading. Merkl scaled incentive campaigns (peak ~2.6K launches) and distributed ~$60M+ in 2025, but user activity appears highly reward-responsive.

bullets: vaults.fyi blue-chip 30-day stablecoin benchmark dipped to ~3.8%.
One-month U.S. T-bill yields ~3.7%; Aave USDC/USDT currently below that rate.
Several large-TVL opportunities returned >10% APY over past 30 days, driven by incentives.
Compression in passive yields pushed capital toward incentive-optimized strategies and active farming.
Pendle separates principal and yield into tradable tokens (PTs and YTs) enabling fixed-yield strategies.
Early 2025 TVL was $4.6B across 4 chains; peaked at $12.9B across 8 chains; fell to ~$3.5B year-end.
Trading volume scaled in 2025, peaking near $12B in September around major maturity cycles.
Pendle generated ~$34M revenue in 2025, with monthly revenue consistently >$1M; introduced Boros for funding-rate trading.
Merkl provides incentive infrastructure for distributing yield-based rewards across protocols and chains.
Campaign creation peaked at ~2.6K new campaigns in July 2025, showing large protocol adoption of programmable incentives.
Monthly reward claimers peaked near ~310K in September 2025, indicating rapid but reward-sensitive user growth.
Merkl distributed ~$60M+ in cumulative rewards during 2025; multiple months exceeded $10M.
Passive stablecoin yields compressing shifts risk/reward — liquidity seeks incentive overlays for higher returns.
Incentive-driven double-digit yields are available but often depend on temporary reward programs.
Pendle's revenue and volumes suggest durable trading demand around yield structuring and rate products.
Merkl scales distribution effectively, but sustaining organic engagement after incentives remains a key risk.

images.title: Blue Chip Stablecoin Benchmark Yield Trend (2025-2026)
images.description: A line chart illustrating the 30-day average 'Blue Chip' stablecoin benchmark yield over a one-year period from January 2025 to January 2026. The data shows a significant downward trend, starting at approximately 12.5% in early January 2025 and dropping sharply to around 8% by February. The yield hits a low of approximately 3.5% in May 2025 before a modest recovery to around 5.5% in late 2025. The chart ends on January 06, 2026, with the benchmark yield at 4% (0.04), though the line dips slightly below this mark. This data indicates a tightening of yields in the stablecoin market, aligning more closely with traditional financial benchmarks like U.S. Treasury bills.

content.title: Stablecoins: Treasury Pivot and Supply Outlook
content.summary: Delphi Digital notes stablecoin issuers now hold over $120B in US government debt as reserves, shifting cash and bank deposits into T-bills, reverse repos, and government-only funds. The US Treasury projects holdings could reach $1T by 2028; Delphi calls 2026 the year stablecoins become a visible buyer base. Growth is flattening after two years; lower front-end yields, cooling trading, and redemption sensitivity could cause short-term supply swings despite a long-term expansion trend.

bullets: Issuers hold >$120B in US government debt, replacing cash/bank buffers with T-bills and reverse repos.
US Treasury projection: holdings could reach $1T by 2028; Delphi highlights 2026 as a visible buyer base year.
After two years of expansion, growth rates have begun to flatten; front-end yields to fall as Fed cuts.
Chart (Dec 1, 2025 data) shows total stablecoin market cap rising to ~$349B, then consolidating before potential expansion.

content.title: Bitcoin Nears Red Yearly Candle
content.summary: Alex Thorn (Galaxy Research) argues Bitcoin is poised to close a red yearly candle: BTCUSD is -6.3% YTD and -8.25% YoY; to finish positive for 2025 it needs a daily close > $93,389 on New Year’s Eve. He cites a -36% drawdown from the Oct 6 ATH ($125,296), U.S. Bitcoin ETP inflows down ~-9% from their October peak, broad whale distribution and the Oct 10 leverage wipeout. On-chain metrics show long-term holder coin declines since July 2025; realized market cap > $1.1T and realized price > $56k. Options expiry and January reallocation are potential near-term catalysts.

bullets: BTCUSD is -6.3% YTD and -8.25% YoY as of this note.
To post a positive 2025 return, BTC needs a daily close above $93,389 on New Year’s Eve.
BTC has fallen ~36% from its Oct 6, 2025 ATH of $125,296.
U.S. Bitcoin ETP cumulative inflows have only drawn down ~-9% from an October $62B peak.

Realized market cap > $1.1T; realized price > $56k — structural metrics indicating broader distribution.
Author: quiet year‑end price action driven by whale distribution, Oct. 10 leverage wipeout and competing macro trades.
A large options expiry could clear dealer gamma that has kept BTC pinned near $85k–$90k.
January reallocation by portfolio managers and major allocators could reignite momentum despite tepid finish.

content.title: Agno Agents 2.0: The Learning Machine Cookbook
content.summary: Agno's "Agents 2.0: The Learning Machine" is a unified system for building AI agents that learn and adapt from every interaction. It coordinates five learning stores: User Profile for structured data, User Memory for unstructured observations, Session Context for task continuity, Entity Memory for facts and relationships, and Learned Knowledge for collective intelligence. The system supports various learning modes (ALWAYS, AGENTIC, PROPOSE) and custom schemas, enabling personalized and intelligent agent behavior. The cookbook provides practical examples and setup instructions for deploying agents with PostgreSQL and OpenAI models, demonstrating incremental profile building, task planning, and knowledge transfer across sessions. Key point: Agno's Learning Machine unifies AI agent learning.

key_points.header: Unified Learning System for AI Agents
bullets: Agno's Learning Machine integrates five core learning stores: User Profile, User Memory, Session Context, Entity Memory, and Learned Knowledge.
Each store handles distinct knowledge types, from structured user preferences to collective insights, enabling comprehensive agent learning.
The system supports various learning modes (ALWAYS, AGENTIC, PROPOSE) and custom schemas for flexible agent development.

key_points.header: Key Learning Stores and Their Functions
bullets: User Profile captures structured user data for personalization, while User Memory stores unstructured observations for contextual understanding.
Session Context tracks conversation state, goals, plans, and progress for task continuity.
Entity Memory builds a knowledge graph of external entities, and Learned Knowledge stores reusable insights via a vector database for semantic search.
The cookbook provides practical examples for setting up and deploying learning agents with PostgreSQL and OpenAI/Claude models.
It demonstrates incremental profile building, task planning, knowledge transfer, and the creation of custom, database-backed learning stores.
The system is designed for extensibility, allowing developers to define custom schemas and integrate bespoke learning mechanisms.

Tether added $48.2B of stablecoin supply in 2025.
