content.title: Claude Code and the Agentic AI Wave
content.summary: Claude Code runs long autonomous coding. Claude Code (Opus 4.5) can autonomously develop, test, and deploy software for hours, demonstrated by a 1h14m run that created a working prompt-store site. Key enablers: long-run compaction, Skills (reusable instruction+tool bundles), subagents, and the Model Context Protocol (MCP). METR shows exponential increases in task-duration capability. Desktop and CLI access exist (desktop $20/mo). Major implications for developers, knowledge workers, and productization of AI-generated work — but serious security and data-risk tradeoffs.

bullets: Claude Code (Opus 4.5) executed a 1h14m autonomous workflow producing a deployed website.
Produced hundreds of code files, a deploy script, and a functioning sales page for prompt packs.
Autonomy extended beyond coding to browser-based user testing and iterative fixes.
Compaction: conversation summaries to preserve progress when context windows fill.
Skills: self-selected instruction/tool bundles that load context and capabilities on demand.
Subagents: specialized lightweight models for parallelized, context-isolated tasks.
Two main interfaces: Command-line (full features) and Claude Desktop (easier, limited features).
Desktop requires subscription (~$20/month) and folder access; CLI exposes more slash commands.
Slash commands enable /agents, /skills and other agent-management actions.
Rapid prototyping: build, test, and deploy small web products with minimal human coding.
Research pipelines: subagents and MCPs let AIs pull domain content (papers, APIs).
Design iteration: AIs can generate, playtest, and refine creative simulations or games.
Security: local file access and code execution can delete or expose sensitive data.
Economic: programming roles will be refactored toward orchestration and AI-harness skills.
Ethical: generated marketing claims, fake reviews, and liability for automated deployments.

images.title: LLM Software Engineering Task Duration Capability Over Time
images.description: A scatter plot and trend line chart from METR showing the exponential increase in the time-horizon of software engineering tasks that different LLMs can complete with a 50% success rate. The x-axis tracks LLM release dates from 2020 to 2025, and the y-axis measures human task duration in hours, ranging from 0 to 5 hours. Early models like GPT-2, GPT-3, and GPT-3.5 (2020-2022) show near-zero capability. GPT-4 (2023) marks the beginning of a sharp upward trend. Projected and recent models for 2025 show significant gains: o4-mini (~1 hour), GPT-5 (~1.75 hours), GPT-5.1-Codex-Max (~2.75 hours), and Claude Opus 4.5 (~4.75 hours). Specific task benchmarks are mapped to the y-axis: training a classifier (~45 min), fixing bugs in small Python libraries (~1 hour), exploiting a buffer overflow in libiec61850 (~2.25 hours), and training an adversarially robust image model (~4 hours). The dashed trend line indicates an accelerating capability for AI to handle increasingly complex and time-consuming autonomous engineering tasks.

images.title: Claude Code Autonomous Startup Development Demo
images.description: A composite screenshot demonstrating the capabilities of Claude Code (v2.0.76) in autonomously developing a software-based startup. The process begins with a user prompt requesting a startup idea that generates $1000/month with zero ongoing effort. The AI agent, powered by Opus 4.5, performs an 'Honest Reality Check' and then proposes a 'Digital Product + Landing Page' system for a Premium AI Prompt Library. The image highlights that Claude Code ran independently for 1 hour and 14 minutes to build the project. The final output includes a terminal message confirming the completion of 'Project Vault' and a screenshot of the resulting website titled 'AI Prompts That Actually Work'. The generated site includes 500 AI prompts across 10 categories such as Business, Marketing, and Coding, with integrated payment options via Gumroad or Lemon Squeezy and a one-command deployment script.

content.title: Vitalik on pluralism, DSA, and platform policy
content.summary: Vitalik criticizes a "no space" approach to content moderation, calling it totalitarian and likely to produce technocratic authoritarianism. He advocates pluralism, user empowerment, algorithmic transparency (publish algorithms with 1–2 year delay plus zk-proofs), privacy-preserving macro-scale community analytics, and incentives for platform openness and interoperability (USB-C analogy). He opposes banning individual anonymity while supporting measures that reduce amplification of harmful content.

bullets: Calling the "no space" refrain totalitarian and anti-pluralistic, especially for subjective, controversial categories.
Argues maximalist removal goals create conflict and empower technocratic enforcement machinery.
Favor a Pirate Party style: user empowerment over top-down bans and expert-driven shifting agendas.
Require algorithmic transparency: publish algorithms with a 1–2 year delay and use zk-proofs to attest to runtime fidelity.
Support incentives for platforms to reduce harmful amplification rather than erecting rigid walls.
Prefer privacy-preserving, macro-scale community analytics to de-anonymization; USB-C analogy used to argue for interoperability.

content.title: Unification vote passes — 100M UNI burn & fee switch
content.summary: Unification governance vote succeeded: 125,342,017 YES vs 742 NO. After an ~2‑day timelock, 100 million UNI will be burned, protocol fee switches flipped, and Uniswap Labs will remove frontend fees and refocus on protocol work. Quorum 40,000,000; vote ended Dec 25, 2025.

bullets: Vote passed overwhelmingly: 125,342,017 FOR vs 742 AGAINST; status SUCCEEDED.
Quorum reported as 40,000,000; vote ended 1:49 pm Dec 25, 2025 (image).
Burn 100,000,000 UNI from the treasury after the ~2‑day timelock.
Flip Uniswap protocol fee switches to route fees into the burn mechanism.
Uniswap Labs to turn off frontend/interface fees and focus resources on protocol work.

images.title: Voting Activity Results
images.description: The image displays the results of a voting activity. The title "Voting activity" is at the top. The voting results are presented with "FOR - 125,342,017" in green and "AGAINST - 742" in red. A progress bar visually represents the votes, with the green portion indicating the "FOR" votes and a small gray portion representing the "AGAINST" votes. Below the voting results, the quorum is stated as "Quorum 40,000,000". The status of the vote is "SUCCEEDED" in green. The voting ended on "Ended 1:49 pm Dec 25, 2025".

content.title: Aptos 2025: performance and institutional adoption
content.summary: Delphi Digital summarizes 2025 Aptos upgrades and ecosystem traction: Baby Raptr and Velociraptr cut finality and block times to ~50ms, making Aptos the fastest major L1 (Chainspect chart). Low on‑chain stablecoin costs ($0.00003 per $200 transfer) coincided with a $1.8B stablecoin market cap and new RWA activity, including a reported $500M BUIDL deployment. New products (DecibelTrade, Shelby) and PACT-driven private credit adoption highlight institutional use cases. Report link included.

bullets: Baby Raptr (June) reduced validator finality latency ~20% by cutting consensus hops from six to four.
Velociraptr (Sept) dropped block times from ~100ms to ~60ms via optimistic proposals.
Aptos now claims ~50ms block production, shown as fastest among major L1s (Chainspect chart, Dec 17, 2025).
Onchain stablecoin transfers cost cited at ~$0.00003 per $200—vs ~$12 on traditional rails; stablecoin market cap hit $1.8B.
BlackRock’s BUIDL fund reportedly deployed an additional $500M in October, making Aptos its second-largest host after Ethereum.
Platforms like PACT enabled private credit onchain; institutional-grade tokenized finance reportedly scaled from near zero over the year.
DecibelTrade: unified onchain spot and perps aiming for CEX-like performance with composability and self‑custody.
Shelby: decentralized hot storage for AI/enterprise workloads; chain‑agnostic with React and Solana SDKs live on devnet.

images.title: Aptos Fastest Block Times Compared to Other L1s
images.description: This image is a bar chart comparing the block production times of several Layer-1 blockchains. The chart's title is "Aptos Sets the Pace: Fastest Block Times Across Major L1s." The y-axis represents "Block Production Time in seconds (s)" and ranges from 0.00s to 0.45s. The x-axis lists the following blockchains: Aptos, Somnia, Sui, Arbitrum, and Solana. The block production times are as follows: Aptos has a block time of 0.05s, Somnia has a block time of 0.10s, Sui has a block time of 0.23s, Arbitrum has a block time of 0.25s, and Solana has a block time of 0.39s. Aptos has the fastest block time. The data is as of December 17, 2025, and the source is Chainspect.

content.title: Senate Republicans race toward crypto vote on bill with uncertain Democratic buy-in
content.summary: Senate Republicans are moving to hold committee markups next week on a U.S. crypto market-structure bill even as key Democrats express reservations. Banking Committee leaders signal a January 15 markup and staff are drafting language for the Responsible Financial Innovation Act, while the Agriculture Committee says it still hopes for bipartisan agreement. Democratic demands — including curbs on senior officials profiting from crypto — could determine whether the bill secures the seven Democratic votes needed for final passage.
bullets: Senate Banking Committee plans a markup around Jan. 15; staff are drafting bill language.
Senate Agriculture Committee leadership professes commitment to bipartisan negotiations but Democratic buy-in remains uncertain.
Key Democratic concerns include preventing senior government officials from profiting from crypto, a potential red line for support.
If both committees pass companion bills, they would be combined for a full Senate vote and likely pass the House, but enough Senate Democrats must stay onboard.

content.title: Kora, Solana 2025 & LazorKit Cookbook
content.summary: Kora enables gasless multi-asset fees. Kora is the Solana Foundation paymaster and signing service enabling gasless UX and multi-token fee collection (USDC, BONK, native SPL). Built on Solana Keychain, it offers TOML-configured policy rules, JSON-RPC and TypeScript SDKs, managed signing backends, Redis caching, rate limiting, Prometheus metrics, and a Runtime Verification audit. DeFi Dev Corp ranks Solana as 2025’s dominant smart-contract platform: ~33B transactions, ~1.1K avg TPS, ~1B new wallets, 10,753 active devs, $1.57T DEX volume, and ~$1.41B onchain revenue. LazorKit Cookbook provides passkey wallets, gasless USDC flows, and sign-once subscription recipes with live demos and full code. Quick hits include ZK/Noir examples, stORE, Paladin/Lifinity shutdowns, tooling links, and hiring listings.

bullets: Solana Foundation-maintained paymaster enabling gasless and multi-asset fee payments.
Accepts USDC, BONK, or native SPL tokens; removes need for end-user SOL.
Configurable via TOML: fee payer policies, allowed methods, token/user allowlists.
Exposes JSON-RPC 2.0 API and TypeScript SDK; supports managed signers and keypairs.
DeFi Dev Corp: ~33B transactions in 2025; ~1.1K average TPS for the year.
~1.01B new wallets; 10,753 active developers — ahead of Ethereum by their measures.
DEX volume ≈ $1.57T; onchain fee revenue ≈ $1.41B; median fee ~0.1¢.
Stablecoin supply cited at $14.8B; tokenized equities volume ~$2.9B in six months.
Open-source recipe collection with live demos and full code for real UX fixes.
Passkey-based wallets: Face ID/Touch ID flows that remove seed-phrase UX friction.
Gasless USDC transfers via paymaster integration so users never touch SOL.
Sign-once flows and subscription POC for recurring automated payments on Solana.
Paladin and Lifinity are shutting down; Paladin obsoleted by upcoming MCP upgrade.
Quick hits: Noir ZK examples, stORE liquid staking, NAV instant-settlement demo, QuickNode review.
Relevant tooling: solana-keychain, tx-indexer, solana-anchor-ai-rules, pinocchio-amm, barrel CLI.
Hiring: DeFiTuna, Jito Labs, Pye, Crossmint; podcast interview with Matty Taylor on 2026 allocation.

images.title: 2025 Blockchain Performance Rankings Comparison
images.description: A comprehensive data table titled 'The 2025 Blockchain Performance Rankings' comparing leading blockchains across eight key metrics. Solana holds the 1st place position in every category listed. For Total Transactions, Solana leads with 33.13B, followed by BNB Chain (4.11B) and Base (3.65B). In Average Daily Transactions Per Second (TPS), Solana records 1.1K, while BNB Chain has 131 and Base has 117. New Wallets Created shows Solana at 1.01B, BNB Chain at 214M, and Sui at 188M. Ecosystem Developers are led by Solana with 10,753, followed by Ethereum with 8,331 and BNB Chain with 3,811. Decentralized Exchange (DEX) Volume ranks Solana first at $1.57T, Ethereum second at $946B, and BNB Chain third at $723B. Total Revenue rankings place Solana at $1.41B, Ethereum at $666M, and TRON at $582M. The Fee Stability Ratio shows Solana at 743, Avalanche at 157, and Base at 31. Finally, Tokenized Stock Volume is led by Solana at $2.9B, BNB Chain at $2B, and Ethereum at $954M. Data sources include Artemis, Blockworks Research, Chainspect, DeFi Dev Corp., and RWA.xyz.

content.title: Morgan Stanley seeks approval for bitcoin, Solana ETFs
content.summary: Morgan Stanley files with the U.S. SEC to launch spot ETFs tracking Bitcoin and Solana, signaling increased institutional push into digital-asset products. The filing follows regulatory shifts (including an OCC letter) that eased bank participation in crypto and arrives amid SEC uncertainty about SOL’s securities status, creating regulatory risk for a Solana ETF.
bullets: Morgan Stanley files to launch ETFs tracking Bitcoin and Solana with the U.S. SEC.
Recent regulatory changes (OCC guidance) and earlier spot BTC ETF approvals have encouraged banks to expand crypto offerings.
SEC’s legal stance that SOL may be a security creates approval risk for a Solana ETF despite rising institutional interest.
Increased bank participation will raise demand for compliance, custody, and transaction surveillance vendors.

content.title: Morgan Stanley Becomes First Major US Bank to File for Proprietary Bitcoin ETF
content.summary: Morgan Stanley filed S-1 forms with the SEC on Jan 6, 2026 to launch proprietary spot Bitcoin and Solana ETFs — the first Big Ten U.S. bank to seek branded crypto ETFs rather than acting only as custodian. The trusts would hold spot assets directly and integrate custody, trading via E*TRADE, and fee capture within Morgan Stanley's wealth platform; the Solana product proposes staking within the ETF wrapper. The filing signals a potential industry shift as major banks may pursue their own crypto products.
bullets: Morgan Stanley filed to create Morgan Stanley Bitcoin Trust and Morgan Stanley Solana Trust (S-1 filed Jan 6, 2026).
Products are proposed as passive spot ETFs that directly hold underlying assets; Solana filing includes staking provisions.
Bank aims to distribute via its wealth management and E*TRADE channels, capturing management fees previously earned by third-party issuers.
Industry observers expect a competitive domino effect with other major banks likely to follow; SEC review is pending.

content.title: Apple‑TSMC: How Apple Built Modern Semiconductors
content.summary: Apple funded TSMC's leading-edge rise. Apple’s annual spend at TSMC grew from ~$2B (2014) to $24B (2025); Apple went from ~9% to ~20–25% of TSMC revenue. Apple consistently took >50% share at new nodes since 20nm, effectively underwriting node development and yield learning. The HPC/AI shift (NVIDIA, hyperscalers) raised TSMC HPC revenue from 36% (2020) to 58% (2025), splitting capex demand between logic (Apple) and CoWoS packaging (NVIDIA). Proprietary Foundry and Apple Wafer Demand models forecast Nvidia overtaking Apple on N3 by 4Q27, Apple reclaiming share on A14, and Apple wafer demand diversifying beyond iPhone into Macs, tablets, and new N/C-series chips. Analysis quantifies capex, wafer flows, packaging economics, Taiwan concentration risk, Arizona ramp limits, and conditions where Apple might partially qualify Intel or Samsung.

bullets: TSMC built 20nm capacity in 2013-14 driven by Apple commitments.
Apple spend grew from $2B (2014) to $24B (2025), funding R&D and capex.
Apple filled 70%+ of 3nm capacity at peaks, de-risking node investments.
HPC revenue rose from 36% (2020) to 58% (2025), smartphones fell to 29%.
NVIDIA and hyperscalers created a second anchor tenant for TSMC capex.
CoWoS packaging (AI) outpaced InFO (mobile); CoWoS revenue surged multi‑billion.
Model shows Nvidia consuming more N3 wafers than Apple by 4Q27.
Apple share of N2 falls below 50% due to HPC-focused A16 architecture.
A14 (1.4nm) designed for both mobile and HPC; Apple reclaims ~67% share on A14.
Apple favors InFO-PoP stacking DRAM over SoC for thickness and thermal limits.
NVIDIA depends on CoWoS with HBM; packaging drives separate capacity planning.
Convergence onto 3D/SoIC for M5/M6 risks future packaging resource contention.
Apple explores Intel 18A-P and Samsung CIS for supply diversification.
Arizona currently supplies <5% of leading-edge; material Taiwan risk persists until 2028+.
Practical diversification focuses on peripherals (PMICs, display drivers) not leading-edge A/M cores.

images.title: TSMC Historical and Projected Financial Performance Metrics (2010-2025)
images.description: A composite of four charts detailing the financial and operational growth of TSMC from 2010 to 2025 (projected). 1. TSMC Revenue ($B): A bar chart showing a steady climb from approximately $13B in 2010 to $35B in 2019, followed by a rapid acceleration to a projected $122B by 2025. 2. TSMC Gross Margins (%): A line chart illustrating margins fluctuating between 45% and 50% for most of the decade, before spiking to nearly 60% in 2022 and trending back toward 60% by 2025. 3. TSMC R&D ($B): A bar chart showing consistent growth in research and development spending, starting at roughly $1B in 2010 and scaling to nearly $8B by 2025. 4. TSMC Capex ($B): A bar chart depicting capital expenditure, which remained under $10B until 2015, rose to $15B in 2019, and then surged to over $35B in 2022, with a 2025 projection of $40B. The data is sourced from the SemiAnalysis Foundry Industry Model and Company Reports, highlighting the massive capital and research intensity required to maintain semiconductor leadership.

images.title: TSMC R&D Spending and Intensity (2010-2025)
images.description: A dual-axis chart illustrating TSMC's Research and Development (R&D) spending and intensity from 2010 to 2025. The orange bars represent absolute R&D spending in billions of dollars ($B) on the left Y-axis, while the blue line with circular markers represents R&D intensity as a percentage of revenue on the right Y-axis. R&D spending shows a steady increase from approximately $1B in 2010 to an accelerated growth phase starting around 2014, reaching $5.8B in 2023 and projected to hit $8B by 2025. R&D intensity fluctuates between 7% and 9%, with peaks around 2013, 2019, and 2023. Despite the record-high absolute spending projected for 2025, the intensity is forecasted to drop back toward 7%. The chart attributes the acceleration in spending since 2014 to Apple's demand for leading-edge semiconductor nodes. Data is sourced from the SemiAnalysis Foundry Industry Model.

content.title: Market Tails and Uncertainty
content.summary: Downside tail risks in rates are underpriced. Markets price cuts for 2026 back-loaded into H2 and into 2027; probability Fed funds reaches 2% is effectively zero. Expect neutral rate ~3.0–3.25%, short-end ~310 bps, 10-year ~410 bps. Z6/Z8 curve could flatten ~65bp by end-2026; 2s10s may steepen ~30bp if inflation remains dominant. Equities show broadening sales and earnings breadth (60% large caps, ~50% mid caps). Labor diffusion remains positive; unemployment likely to peak ~4.7% then ease. GDP ~2.5% real, nominal ~5%. Constructive for small caps and financials if short rates fall and curve steepens.

bullets: Downside tail risk, especially in rates, appears underpriced entering 2026.
Policy uncertainty centers on inflation persistence versus labor-market deterioration.
Market pricing leans toward inflation dominance, limiting perceived chance of deep cuts.
Cuts priced for 2026 are back-loaded into H2 and extend into 2027.
Market-implied path implies neutral policy near 3.00–3.25%; Fed funds reaching 2% is unlikely.
Expect Z6/Z8 flattening ~65bp by year-end 2026 and short end around 310bps.
10-year anchored near 410bps; 2s10s could steepen ~30bp if inflation remains controlling factor.
Sales breadth healthy: ~60% large caps, ~50% mid caps reporting YoY sales growth.
Net employment breadth remains modestly positive, consistent with a soft-landing scenario.
Layoffs are concentrated; diffusion metrics not signaling broad-based jobless surge yet.
CapEx recovery led by Industrials and Information Technology; breadth remains below prior peaks.
AI-related R&D is a primary driver of increased capex breadth in IT.
Wider participation in productive capex will determine durability of the investment upswing.
Expect unemployment to peak near 4.7% and decline toward ~4.3% by end-2026.
Inflation to peak near 3% (±15bps) and drift toward ~2.5% by late-2026.
Real GDP forecast ~2.5% in 2026; nominal growth nearer 5%, supporting a relatively steep curve.
Environment favors small caps and financials via lower short rates and improved net interest margins.

images.title: Implied Fed Funds Rate Path and Cumulative Basis Points Priced (2026-2027)
images.description: A dual-axis chart showing the market-implied path for the Federal Funds Rate and the cumulative basis points priced in from January 2026 to April 2027. The left y-axis measures the Implied Fed Funds Rate as a percentage, represented by a dark green line with markers. This rate starts at approximately 3.6% in January 2026 and trends downward throughout the year, reaching a low of roughly 3.12% in December 2026 before slightly rising to 3.15% by April 2027. The right y-axis measures Cumulative Basis Points Priced, shown as tan-colored bars extending downward from the zero line. These bars indicate a progressive increase in priced-in cuts, starting near 0 in early 2026 and reaching a cumulative total of approximately -50 basis points by December 2026, where it remains relatively stable through April 2027. The data indicates that markets expect the majority of rate cuts to occur in the second half of 2026, with a terminal rate expectation around 3.1-3.2%.

images.title: US Treasury Yields and 2s10s Spread Forecast (2021-2026)
images.description: A line chart from LSEG displaying historical data and future forecasts for US Treasury yields and the yield curve spread from January 2021 to early 2026. The chart tracks three primary metrics: the 2-year Treasury yield (purple), the 10-year Treasury yield (red), and the 2s10s spread (dark green). Historically, both the 2-year and 10-year yields rose sharply from near-zero and 1% respectively in early 2021 to peaks around 5% in late 2023. The 2s10s spread inverted in mid-2022, reaching a low of approximately -1.0% in mid-2023. The forecast section, starting in early 2026, projects the 10-year yield (black line) to stabilize around 4.1%, the 2-year yield (orange line) to decline toward 3.1%, and the 2s10s spread (yellow line) to steepen and return to positive territory, reaching approximately 1.1%. The Y-axis represents percentage yields ranging from -2.00 to 6.00.

content.title: Bitcoin Long-Term Capital Market Assumptions
content.summary: 15% base-case CAGR to $2.9M by 2050. A 25-year CMA models Bitcoin as a low-correlation, convex reserve asset with Bear/Base/Bull price paths ($130k / $2.9M / $53.4M). Long-term volatility assumed 40–70% annualized; correlation to global liquidity (M2) is material. Drivers: settlement adoption (5–10% trade), central bank reserve allocations (2.5% balance sheets). Tactical signals: RUP, futures funding, and open interest guide 2026 entry timing. Strategic allocation recommended 1–3% (optimizations up to 20% for high risk tolerance); 3% often maximizes Sharpe in a 60/40 portfolio.

bullets: Base Case: 15% CAGR implies $2.9M per BTC by 2050.
Bear Case: 2% CAGR ($130k); Bull Case: 29% CAGR ($53.4M).
Strategic allocation: 1–3%; up to 20% for high risk tolerance.
Bitcoin framed as a reserve asset and sovereign-risk hedge.
TAM split: Medium of Exchange and Central Bank Reserves drive value.
Base adoption: 5–10% of international trade; 5% domestic trade assumption.
Bull adoption: 20% trade share and 10% domestic GDP produces $53.4M price.
Scenarios use $88k (12/31/2025) as baseline for CAGR calculations.
Expected returns: Base 15% CAGR; Bear 2%.
Volatility: 40–70% annualized for long-horizon stress testing.
Correlation: Low to equities/bonds/gold; long-term inverse to DXY.
Global M2 changes explain ~54% of price variance in multivariable tests.
Derivatives leverage matters: futures open interest explains ~73% of price variance since Oct 2020.
Leverage beta averages 0.68x, spikes to 2.0x during stress.
Realized volatility has compressed to ~27% recently due to market maturation.
Asian trading hours now lead global price discovery.
Monitor Relative Unrealized Profit (RUP); 30DMA >0.70 historically signals cycle tops.
Perpetual funding above ~10% signals excessive leverage; current ~4.9% implies upside risk.
Recommend disciplined position sizing to capture convex returns while limiting portfolio volatility.
3% addition to 60/40 historically improved Sharpe and return per unit risk.

images.title: VanEck Bitcoin Long-Term Capital Market Assumptions Article
images.description: A screenshot of a VanEck research article titled 'Bitcoin Long-Term Capital Market Assumptions' dated January 08, 2026. The article, authored by Matthew Sigel and Patrick Bush, outlines a base-case projection for Bitcoin reaching a $2.9 million valuation by 2050, representing a 15% CAGR. Key takeaways include: 1) Structural Valuation: The $2.9M target is driven by Bitcoin's adoption as a settlement currency for 5-10% of global trade and its use as a reserve asset comprising 2.5% of central bank balance sheets. 2) Strategic Portfolio Role: A recommended strategic allocation of 1-3% for diversified portfolios, with historical data suggesting up to 20% for optimized Sharpe ratios. 3) Opportunity Cost: The text warns against zero exposure to Bitcoin as a non-sovereign reserve asset during a sovereign debt super-cycle. The article frames Bitcoin's evolution from a speculative asset to an institutionally integrated monetary instrument.

content.title: CLARITY Act headed for markup next week: Senator Tim Scott
content.summary: Sen. Tim Scott says the CLARITY Act — legislation to create a comprehensive U.S. crypto market-structure framework — is scheduled for Senate markup next week. The bill, passed by the House in July 2025, could move to the President if the Senate approves it unchanged. Industry voices remain divided over provisions addressing illicit finance, DeFi front-ends, and OFAC powers, and some analysts link regulatory uncertainty around the bill to recent capital outflows.
bullets: Sen. Tim Scott says the CLARITY Act will go to Senate markup next week and a vote on market structure is expected.
If the Senate passes the bill without changes, it would go directly to the President; the House already approved it in July 2025.
Industry stakeholders debate provisions on illicit finance, DeFi front-ends, and expanded OFAC powers; Democrats push changes, some view requests as reasonable.
CoinShares and others attribute some recent crypto fund outflows to prolonged regulatory uncertainty around the CLARITY Act.

content.title: Suavemente: Venezuela, Oil, and Bitcoin
content.summary: US control of Venezuelan oil drives macro: Bitcoin likely benefits if the US prints aggressively while keeping gasoline prices low. Thesis links Trump’s political imperative to inflate nominal GDP, suppress oil prices, and thus sustain risk assets. Monitor WTI/Brent, 10-year yields, and MOVE volatility to know when credit expansion stalls and risk assets weaken. Tactical allocations: long Bitcoin and privacy bets (ZEC), fund privacy/DeFi positions by trimming BTC/ETH exposure; avoid oversized memecoin bets despite occasional gains.

bullets: Trump’s re-election incentives drive policies to boost nominal GDP via credit expansion.
Controlling Venezuelan oil aims to cap gasoline inflation, preserving voter support.
Nominal GDP up plus low oil prices = political victory for incumbents.
Gasoline price moves three months before elections correlate with control shifts.
Rising oil pushes 10-year yields and MOVE index higher, forcing policy reversals.
If oil spikes, politicians may curb money printing, hurting risk assets.
Bitcoin is framed as a monetary hedge: benefits from broad dollar liquidity expansion.
Energy price is secondary; oil matters through its influence on policy and yields.
Watch USD Liquidity Conditions, WTI/Brent, 10-year yield, and MOVE for regime shifts.
Maelstrom enters 2026 highly risk‑on: low stablecoin holdings, large BTC exposure.
Sell BTC to fund privacy bets and sell ETH to fund DeFi positions.
Focus on one breakout privacy shitcoin (ZEC as privacy beta) and size smaller memecoin wagers.
Reduce risk if oil and yields spike; take profits into sats and mETH when credit tightens.
Charts and tables show historical links between gasoline moves and political control.
Policymakers will react to asset and oil price signals; market reflexivity simplifies responses.
Actionable signal: diverging GDP and oil trends determine risk-on vs risk-off regimes.

images.title: Polymarket Prediction: 2026 US House Election Odds
images.description: A line chart from the Polymarket prediction platform displays the odds for the 2026 US House of Representatives election. The chart tracks two outcomes: 'Democratic Party' (blue line) and 'Republican Party' (red line). As of early January, the Democratic Party is favored with a 79% probability, while the Republican Party is at 22%. The market has a total volume of $1,481,828 and is scheduled to resolve on November 3, 2026. The historical data shows a significant shift starting in November, where the Democratic Party's odds increased from approximately 60% to nearly 80%, while the Republican Party's odds decreased from approximately 40% to 22%. The interface also shows options for different timeframes (1H, 6H, 1D, 1W, 1M, ALL) and a 4% earn rate on positions.

images.title: US Opinion Poll: Most Important Issues by Age Group (Oct 2025)
images.description: A horizontal bar chart detailing the results of a US opinion poll from October 2025 by The Economist/YouGov. It compares the priorities of two age groups: 18-29 (green) and 65+ (dark blue). Inflation is the leading concern for both, at approximately 20% and 22% respectively. Jobs & Economy is a major outlier for the 18-29 group, cited as the most important issue by roughly 21%, while only 8% of the 65+ group agree. Health Care is prioritized by the 65+ group at 14%, double the 7% recorded for the 18-29 group. National Security shows the largest disparity, with 9% of the 65+ group marking it as the top issue compared to just 1% of the 18-29 group. Other issues like Civil Rights, Immigration, and Climate Change show smaller differences between the demographics.

content.title: Morgan Stanley Files for Bitcoin and Solana ETFs With the SEC
content.summary: Morgan Stanley files with the U.S. SEC to launch spot price-linked ETFs for bitcoin and solana. If approved, the ETFs would let investors gain exposure to BTC and SOL via brokerage accounts without direct custody. The filings signal growing institutional support for multi-asset crypto ETFs and mark further mainstream integration of digital assets.
bullets: Morgan Stanley files regulatory documents to create spot ETFs tied to bitcoin and solana.
Approval would allow investors to access BTC and SOL through traditional brokerage and retirement accounts without holding tokens directly.
Solana inclusion is notable — suggests regulators and institutions may consider assets beyond bitcoin for spot ETF structures.
The move aligns with broader U.S. regulatory shifts easing bank participation and follows other large managers filing crypto ETFs.

content.title: Morgan Stanley Joins Wall Street's Crypto Bandwagon With ETF Bid
content.summary: Morgan Stanley filed paperwork on Jan. 6, 2026 for two spot cryptocurrency trusts — a Bitcoin Trust and a Solana Trust — marking the firm's first move into retail-style crypto ETFs. The Solana product would include a portion of assets allocated to staking to generate on‑chain rewards. Both trusts would be sponsored by Morgan Stanley Investment Management.
bullets: Morgan Stanley submits filings for a Bitcoin Trust and a Solana Trust, its first crypto fund filings.
The Solana trust would allocate a portion of holdings to staking to earn rewards.
Trusts would be sponsored by Morgan Stanley Investment Management and hold the underlying tokens.
Filing follows broader industry trend of Wall Street firms offering spot crypto ETFs since 2024–2025.

content.title: Morgan Stanley Plans to Launch Bitcoin and Solana ETFs
content.summary: Morgan Stanley has filed applications with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to launch exchange-traded funds providing exposure to Bitcoin and Solana, according to the Wall Street Journal. The move follows rapid growth in U.S. spot Bitcoin ETFs since 2024 and signals continued traditional-finance interest in crypto ETF products.
bullets: WSJ reports Morgan Stanley submitted SEC filings to create Bitcoin and Solana ETFs.
The filings come after strong growth of existing spot Bitcoin ETFs, which manage over $120 billion.
The proposed Solana ETF would mark another large financial institution offering crypto exposure beyond Bitcoin.

content.title: The Daily: Morgan Stanley files for spot Bitcoin and Solana ETFs as inflows enter 2026 'like a lion,' and more
content.summary: Morgan Stanley files for spot Bitcoin and Solana ETFs, signaling increased institutional interest while inflows into crypto start 2026 strongly. The item is a roundup highlighting ETF filing activity and broader inflow momentum into major assets like BTC and SOL.
bullets: Morgan Stanley files for spot Bitcoin and Solana ETFs, marking an institutional ETF push.
Market inflows into crypto enter 2026 with strong momentum, described as coming in 'like a lion.'
Coverage is a daily roundup summarizing ETF activity and flow dynamics for major assets such as BTC and SOL.

content.title: Morgan Stanley Files to Launch Crypto ETFs, Joining a Crowded Field
content.summary: Morgan Stanley files with the SEC to register two exchange-traded funds tied to the prices of Bitcoin and Solana. The move would make Morgan Stanley the first major bank with a large wealth-management arm to offer crypto price-linked ETFs, entering an already crowded market of more than 100 crypto ETFs.
bullets: Morgan Stanley files to register two ETFs tracking Bitcoin and Solana prices with the SEC.
If approved, Morgan Stanley becomes the first major bank with a large wealth-management arm to offer such funds.
The crypto ETF market already exceeds 100 products, so the new filings add competition rather than creating a unique product.
Filing signals continued institutionalization of crypto products within traditional wealth-management channels.

content.title: 'Very Surprised'—Bitcoin And Crypto Braced For Huge $8 Trillion Wall Street Price 'Shocker'
content.summary: Forbes reports that Wall Street banks, including Morgan Stanley, are moving deeper into bitcoin and crypto—filing for spot bitcoin and Solana ETFs—which could mobilize up to $8 trillion in advisory assets and materially affect prices. The piece frames recent bitcoin gains and fragile ETF flows as backdrop, quoting analysts who call the bank ETF filings a surprise that could add legitimacy and accelerate institutional adoption.
bullets: Morgan Stanley filed for spot bitcoin and spot Solana ETFs, prompting surprise among ETF analysts.
Analysts highlight Morgan Stanley’s ~$8 trillion advisory asset base as a potential source of large inflows to its own branded funds.
Bitcoin has rallied ~10% since December lows but ETF flows have shown stop-start patterns, making the rally fragile.
Market commentators warn short-term ETF inflows/outflows may drive volatility rather than a sustained trend.

content.title: Morgan Stanley seeks SEC approval to become first major U.S. bank to launch crypto price ETFs
content.summary: Morgan Stanley filed with the SEC to launch exchange-traded funds that track the prices of Bitcoin and Solana, potentially becoming the first major U.S. bank to offer token-linked ETFs rather than just custody services. The move reflects growing regulatory clarity and institutional demand for ETF-based crypto exposure, and signals a strategic shift by big banks toward active product creation in digital assets.
bullets: Morgan Stanley submitted SEC filings to offer ETFs tied directly to Bitcoin and Solana prices.
If approved, the bank would be the first major U.S. bank to launch ETFs linked to tokens instead of only providing custody.
Regulatory changes and clearer guidance (e.g., OCC intermediary permission, revised SEC listing rules) are enabling banks to offer crypto products.
Institutional and wealth clients prefer ETF exposure for liquidity, tax treatment, and regulatory guardrails; rivals are also expanding crypto access.

content.title: Morgan Stanley Unveils Spot Bitcoin and Solana ETFs
content.summary: Morgan Stanley files with the SEC to launch spot Bitcoin and spot Solana ETFs on Jan. 6, marking the first major U.S. bank entry into spot crypto ETFs. Analysts call the move a surprise and note Morgan Stanley can leverage its ~$8–9T advisory assets to capture flows rather than outsourcing to incumbents like BlackRock. The item contrasts strong early-2026 BTC ETF inflows with more modest Solana ETF activity since October.
bullets: Morgan Stanley filed with the SEC to create spot Bitcoin and spot Solana ETFs on Jan. 6, 2026.
Analysts (e.g., Eric Balchunas) called the filings a "shocker" and framed the move as strategically sensible given Morgan Stanley's large advisory asset base.
Bitcoin ETFs have seen strong net inflows in early 2026; spot Solana ETFs have had modest cumulative flows and daily inflows since October.
Morgan Stanley becomes the first major U.S. bank to enter the spot crypto ETF market, competing with issuers like BlackRock, Invesco, Fidelity and Grayscale.

content.title: Morgan Stanley Registers Bitcoin and Solana Funds With SEC
content.summary: Morgan Stanley filed S-1 registration forms with the SEC for spot Bitcoin and Solana exchange-traded products named Morgan Stanley Bitcoin Trust and Morgan Stanley Solana Trust. The filings describe passive funds that will track BTC and SOL prices but do not yet disclose custodians, counterparties, or final fee schedules. The move positions Morgan Stanley to offer direct institutional-style exposure to BTC and SOL following the growth of crypto ETFs since 2024.
bullets: Morgan Stanley submitted S-1 forms to register spot Bitcoin and Solana ETFs (Morgan Stanley Bitcoin Trust; Morgan Stanley Solana Trust).
The funds are described as passive vehicles to track BTC and SOL prices; custodians, counterparties, and fees are not yet specified.
Bitcoin ETFs now account for about $119B AUM; Solana ETFs are a newer cohort that began trading in October 2025.
Morgan Stanley is using its brand directly rather than a joint-venture white-label sponsor.

content.title: Morgan Stanley files S-1s for Bitcoin and Solana ETFs in latest crypto push
content.summary: Morgan Stanley files preliminary S-1 registration forms with the U.S. SEC to launch two spot-style ETFs — a Morgan Stanley Bitcoin Trust and a Morgan Stanley Solana Trust — as passive vehicles that would hold and track the underlying tokens. The filings name Morgan Stanley Investment Management as sponsor and CSC Delaware Trust Company as trustee, disclose cold/hot key custody split, and signal potential new institutional inflows from the bank’s wealth-management client base if approved.
bullets: Morgan Stanley filed S-1s with the SEC proposing a Bitcoin Trust and a Solana Trust as passive spot-like ETFs.
Morgan Stanley Investment Management is listed as sponsor; CSC Delaware Trust Company is trustee; custodial details remain partly unspecified.
Filings state the funds will track the underlying tokens and avoid speculative sales; they could channel inflows from Morgan Stanley’s ~19M wealth-management clients.
The move follows growing institutional adoption and recent ETF inflows, highlighting expanding Wall Street interest in regulated crypto products.

content.title: The Year in Charts — 2025 Sector Review
content.summary: Four subsectors led crypto in 2025: stablecoins, RWAs, perp DEXs, and prediction markets. Overall crypto market cap fell 11% to $3.06T while stablecoins grew 50% to >$300B. Tether and USDC hold 88% share; next-eight stablecoins added $19B led by Sky's USDS. Tokenized stocks exploded (+2,695% YTD), led by Backed, Ondo, Dinari, and Robinhood (tokenizing on Arbitrum). Onchain perp DEX volume rose, with Solana DEX volume surpassing CEXs in Q3; Oct 10 flash crash slowed but didn't reverse the trend. Prediction markets show rising volume but slower open interest growth, splitting attention-driven trading from longer-horizon hedging.

bullets: Crypto market cap declined 11% in 2025 to $3.06T.
Four subsectors—stablecoins, RWAs, perp DEXs, prediction markets—drove disproportionate growth.
Newsletter contributors: RWA.xyz, Token Terminal, Chaos Labs, and Diego Cabral.
Stablecoin market grew 50% in 2025, surpassing $300B total market cap.
Tether (USDT) and USDC combined for 88% market share.
Next eight stablecoins added ~$19B; Sky's USDS led gains.
Notable gainers: PayPal PYUSD (+$3.4B), USD1 (+$2.8B), USDf (+$2.2B).
Regulatory clarity (GENIUS Act) and neobank adoption could accelerate 2026 usage.
Tokenized stocks grew 2,695% YTD, outpacing other tokenized asset categories.
Commodities +225%, funds +148%, stablecoins +49% YTD by comparison.
Leading issuers: Backed, Ondo, Dinari, Robinhood; tokenization playbook now established.
Market opportunity tied to ~$130T public equities market; next 12–18 months will reveal market leaders.
Onchain perp liquidity expanded; DEX perps began overtaking centralized venue share.
Solana DEX volume exceeded CEX volume in Q3 2025, driven by onchain perps.
Oct 10 flash crash created headwinds but did not reverse structural shift toward DEX perps.
Trend likely to broaden to other chains as leverage and liquidity concentrate onchain.
Volume continued growing, but open interest rose much more slowly.
Divergence signals separation between attention-driven trading and capital committed to hedge risk.
Prediction markets evolving into risk-pricing instruments for both short and longer horizons.
Kalshi onchain volume excluded; its onchain notional remained immaterial versus sector weekly volumes.

content.title: Institutions Go On‑Chain in 2025
content.summary: Institutions moved on‑chain in 2025. Major banks and asset managers tokenized funds, issued regulated stablecoins, and integrated blockchain settlement rails. JPMorgan launched a tokenized money‑market fund on Ethereum; SoFi issued a public stablecoin (SoFiUSD); Goldman, BNY Mellon, Deutsche Bank, BNP Paribas, HSBC, and Standard Chartered expanded custody, tokenization, or privacy‑chain participation. Fintechs added market infrastructure (Robinhood tokenized stocks, Revolut joined Pyth, Mastercard + Chainlink integration, Visa settlements using USDC). TradFi asset managers added ~$5.4B on‑chain; PayPal PYUSD grew ~8× to $4B. Markets: low holiday volume, BTC consolidating, ETH/BTC supported by its 200‑day average.

bullets: JPMorgan Asset Management launched a tokenized money‑market fund on Ethereum.
SoFi Bank issued SoFiUSD, a 1:1 cash‑backed public blockchain stablecoin.
Goldman Sachs and BNY Mellon announced support for tokenized money‑market funds.
Selected TradFi managers added roughly $5.4B on‑chain in 2025.
Janus Henderson added ~$1.3B; BlackRock ~$1.1B; WisdomTree ~$700M; China Asset Management added ~$800M.
Alternative institutional funds collectively increased tokenized exposure by about $1.2B.
PayPal PYUSD supply rose from $500M to $4B in 2025 (≈8× growth).
Visa enabled settlement using USDC on its payment network for U.S. banks.
Societe Generale announced a USD‑pegged stablecoin to run on Ethereum and Solana.
Robinhood launched tokenized U.S. stocks and crypto futures on blockchain rails.
Revolut joined Pyth Network as a real‑time data publisher for DeFi price feeds.
Mastercard partnered with Chainlink to allow cardholders to buy crypto on‑chain.
Global crypto market cap down ~0.7% last week, around $3T.
BTC trading in a consolidation wedge; ETH/BTC holding near its 200‑day moving average.
Holiday liquidity is low — volumes at 2025 lows and volatility subdued.

content.title: Prediction Markets at Scale: 2026 Outlook
content.summary: Regulatory tolerance now determines scale. Prediction markets grew sharply in 2025 as mainstream brokerages and sportsbooks (Robinhood, DraftKings, FanDuel) rolled out event contracts and on-chain venues (Polymarket, Opinion Trade) amassed billions in notional volume. Growth is colliding with U.S. and state-level enforcement (CT, NV), pushing firms to design products around jurisdictional compliance, settlement definitions, and KYC/AML. The 2026 FIFA World Cup is a full-stack stress test for liquidity, settlement, payments (USDC/USDC-on-chain pilots), and distribution — likely forcing consolidation, tighter standards, or exits.

bullets: Scale now driven by regulatory tolerance and distribution, not pure product novelty.
Platforms that prove compliant, robust settlement, and wide distribution gain durable advantage.
The 2026 World Cup is a five-week operational and regulatory stress test for markets.
CFTC allowed a narrow class of event contracts; political markets remain contested.
State actions (Connecticut, Nevada) issued cease-and-desist orders against sports-like markets.
Jurisdictional rollout, contract wording, and settlement design now prioritize legal classification.
Polymarket and other crypto venues delivered huge volumes but faced enforcement and geofencing.
On-chain benefits: rapid market creation, 24/7 settlement, global liquidity; downsides: oracle/governance disputes and enforcement risk.
Successful on-chain players must pair rapid access with compliance guardrails or accept restricted jurisdictional footprints.
Sports drive continuous flow with many small bets; politics/macro attract larger, capital-driven positions.
2025 notional volume expanded ~10x versus 2024, ~ $13B/month by late 2025 per industry estimates.
Integrity risks concentrate in capital-heavy non-sports markets; governance disputes scale with open interest.
Stablecoins (USDC) becoming settlement middleware; Visa/USDC pilots enable 24/7 bank settlement.
Super-app distribution (brokerages, sportsbooks) is the dominant moat for liquidity and trust.
Consumer token models (Sport.Fun) show token sales post-product-market-fit, an 'ICO 2.0' pattern.

images.title: Prediction Market Platforms: Regime, Core Product, Distribution, and Key Risks
images.description: This image is a table comparing various prediction market platforms, outlining their regulatory regime and licensing, core product offerings, distribution models, and key risks. The platforms listed include Kalshi (US), FanDuel "Predicts" (US), DraftKings "Predictions" (US), Polymarket (Global), Betfair Exchange (UK), and Robinhood "Prediction Markets Hub" (US). Kalshi operates as a CFTC-regulated exchange with no sports betting license, offering event futures on economics, politics, and sports, with a direct retail platform and faces regulatory constraints and state-level legal challenges. FanDuel "Predicts" is CFTC-regulated via a CME event market, without a state sports betting license in launch states, offering sports and macro event contracts, and leverages its existing sportsbook user base, facing state regulatory issues and user confusion. DraftKings "Predictions" is CFTC-regulated via CME, offering sports event contracts, and uses its app and web platform, facing similar regulatory risks and competition. Polymarket is largely unregulated, offering decentralized prediction markets, using a Crypto/Web3 native interface, and faces regulatory enforcement and reputational risks. Betfair Exchange is UK Gambling Commission licensed, offering peer-to-peer betting, with direct-to-consumer distribution, and faces regulatory changes. Robinhood "Prediction Markets Hub" operates via CFTC-registered FCM and DCM, offering integrated event contracts, with a large user base, and faces regulatory arbitrage risks.

content.title: Awesome CEO: Startup Founder & Leader Resources
content.summary: This repository, "Awesome CEO," is a curated and opinionated list of resources for startup founders and leaders of high-growth companies. It covers essential topics such as fundraising, entrepreneurship, product development, sales, marketing, management, hiring, and finance. The collection includes guides from YCombinator, Dropbox, Stripe, and a16z, along with insights from prominent figures like Sam Altman and Peter Thiel. It also features tools like equity dilution calculators, angel investor directories, and pitch deck collections. The resource emphasizes practical advice for navigating startup challenges, building strong teams, and achieving product-market fit. Key point: Curated resources for startup founders and leaders.

bullets: The repository organizes resources into key areas: Fundraising, Entrepreneurship, Product, Sales, Marketing, Management, Hiring, and Finance.
Each section contains curated links to articles, guides, and tools from reputable sources like YCombinator, a16z, Stripe, and industry leaders.
It provides practical advice and frameworks for various stages of startup development and leadership challenges.
Includes guides on seed fundraising, pitch deck creation, and insights into VC expectations and valuation discussions.
Offers tools like equity dilution calculators and directories of angel investors (First Round Capital, NFX).
Covers financial planning, budgeting, and negotiation strategies for suppliers.

key_points.header: Product Development and Management Best Practices

Provides resources on achieving product-market fit and conducting effective customer interviews (The Mom Test).
Features insights on effective executive leadership, team management, and building strong company culture.

content.title: Payments in the Agentic Economy
content.summary: Stablecoins + HTTP 402 enable machine-to-machine micropayments, but agentic commerce lacks trust infrastructure. x402 (HTTP 402 revival) and pay-per-crawl make pay-per-request practical; OpenAI's ACP and Google's AP2/Agent2Agent provide intent/auth flows. Card rails offer dispute protections but are slow and expensive; crypto rails are fast/cheap but irreversible. Key missing layers: Know-Your-Agent identity, shared fraud detection (fraud graph), reputation, and recourse/escrow (deferred settlement). Startups can wedge into identity, recourse (insurance/escrow), and attribution; incumbents (Visa/Stripe/Cloudflare/AI labs) have distribution or data advantages but misaligned incentives.

bullets: Stablecoins+HTTP 402 enable instant, low-cost micropayments for AI agents.
Trust infrastructure (identity, fraud detection, recourse) is missing for agentic payments.
Startups can capture value by productising identity, escrow/recourse, and attribution layers.
OpenAI's ACP connects agents to merchants while keeping humans in checkout loops.
Google's A2A and AP2 aim for agent interoperability, tool access (MCP), and payments.
x402 (Coinbase/Cloudflare implementations) turns HTTP 402 into pay-per-request micropayments.
Card networks provide dispute resolution and broad distribution but are slow and costly.
Crypto rails settle in seconds at low cost but are irreversible and lack chargeback mechanisms.
x402 on chains like Base offers sub-second response and minimal nominal gas costs.
Identity: no persistent KYA (Know Your Agent) layer linking agents to humans/orgs.
Fraud detection: no shared fraud graph to flag anomalous agent behaviour.
Recourse: need deferred settlement/escrow or insurance to enable reversible outcomes.
Phase 1: agent as interface — incumbents control distribution (ACP integrations).
Phase 2: supervised execution — demand for identity and recourse; startups can win.
Phase 3: autonomous agent commerce — reputation, passports, and adjudication define winners.

images.title: Trust Infrastructure Gap: Human Commerce vs. Agent Commerce
images.description: This infographic compares the trust infrastructure in Human Commerce and Agent Commerce across different stages of a transaction. The "BEFORE TRANSACTION" section for Human Commerce lists "Plaid, KYC, SSN" for identity, "Visa, Stripe Radar" for fraud detection, and "Credit scores, ratings" for reputation. In contrast, Agent Commerce relies on "Wallet address, API key" for identity, has "Nothing shared" for fraud detection, and lacks a history, resulting in "No history" for reputation. The "AFTER TRANSACTION" section details recourse and settlement. Human Commerce offers "Chargebacks" and "Hold periods, disputes," while Agent Commerce features "Transaction final" with "Stablecoins settle in seconds" and "Instant and irreversible" settlement. The infographic highlights the challenges and differences in building trust in the emerging agentic economy.

images.title: AI Agent Payment Process Comparison: Existing vs. X402
images.description: This infographic compares the existing payment process for AI agents with a new process using X402. The "EXISTING PROCESS" involves five steps: 1. User Action: Create account with new API provider (Time-consuming setup); 2. User Action: Add payment method to API provider (KYC required -> Delays access, requires approval); 3. User Action: Buy credits / subscription (Prepaid commitment -> Overpay or run out of funds); 4. User Action: Manage API key (Security risk -> Must store & rotate keys); 5. User Action: Make payment (Slow transactions, chargebacks, fees). The "PROCESS WITH X402" streamlines the process with three steps: 1. Agentic Action: AI agent sends HTTP request and receives 402 (Payment Required) (No account setup, instant onboarding); 2. Agentic Action: AI agent pays seamlessly with stablecoins, no signups or approvals required; 3. Agentic Action: API access granted (No manual approvals, no API key management). The text at the bottom highlights that X402 eliminates friction, allowing AI agents to pay per use with zero manual steps.

content.title: Layer 2s: Sector Overview — Base & Arbitrum
content.summary: Base leads L2 revenue; October apps hit $228M. Top 3 L2s now generate over 90% of app revenue (Base ~55%, Arbitrum One ~32%, Linea ~4.5%). Combined L2 app revenue is ~6x smaller than Ethereum L1, narrowing from 15x in 2023. 101 L2s exceed $100k TVS. Blobs grew share from ~41% to 54% over six months. Base all-time revenue ~$178M; Arbitrum $134M; Optimism $115M. Base daily transactions ~10M; all-time ~5B. Solana–Base bridge moved ~43.8K SOL; >83% of bridged assets parked in Uniswap and Aerodrome pools. ArbitrumDAO hit $4.4M monthly revenue in October and may introduce a native stablecoin in 2026.

bullets: Layer 2 app revenue hit a record $228M in October 2025.
Top three L2s account for >90% of app revenue concentration.
Market share gap with Ethereum L1 is narrowing rapidly.
101 L2s have >$100k total value secured; churn pruning weaker chains.
L2 app revenue gap vs Ethereum L1 fell from 15x (2023) to ~6x.
Ethereum blob usage rose from ~41% to 54% in six months.
Base all-time app revenue ~ $178M, ~24% of total L2 revenue.
Daily averages ~10M transactions; all-time transactions near 5B.
Solana–Base bridge initial transfers ~43.8K SOL; >83% parked in Uniswap/Aerodrome.
Arbitrum all-time app revenue ~ $134M; October monthly revenue peaked $4.4M.
ArbitrumDAO aims to outgrow Base via revenue-driven ecosystem investments.
Arbitrum may introduce a native stablecoin in 2026; potential yield-backed economics modeled.
High-throughput L2s (MegaETH, Rise/Celestia) could shift data-availability patterns.
Blobs and upcoming BPO forks may increase onchain data capacity.
Celo shows notable micro-payment activity with ~400k daily active addresses on one contract.

content.title: Inside Talus: Infrastructure for Onchain Agents
content.summary: Talus builds a decentralized execution and settlement layer for autonomous onchain agents: verifiable DAG workflows on Sui, offchain compute via a Leader network, Walrus storage for large state, and a $US token economy for payments, staking, and governance. Nexus encodes workflows onchain, Leaders run offchain tools and submit cryptographic receipts, and tools register pricing and access. Design priorities: deterministic, auditable state transitions; hybrid onchain/offchain execution; delivery-versus-payment gas budgeting; progressive decentralization of Leaders; and economic primitives to enable agent-to-agent markets and custody of assets.

bullets: Centralized AI infra is opaque, brittle, and unsuitable for multi-party autonomous agents.
Agents need persistence, verifiability, cryptographic permissions, and native economic participation.
Current API/model providers create dependency, unpredictable pricing, and no auditable proofs.
Nexus stores workflow DAGs and state transitions on Sui using Move and object-centric state.
Leaders coordinate offchain compute, execute tools, and submit verifiable receipts onchain.
Walrus provides decentralized offchain storage with onchain commitments for large agent memory.
Workflows encoded as DAGs: nodes are tool invocations or state updates; executions tracked as DAGExecution objects.
Walk states (Active, Successful, Failed, Consumed) provide liveness, fallbacks, and error handling.
Offchain compute performs heavy tasks; cryptographic commitments settle results onchain for auditability.
$US token used for payments, staking, governance, tool registration, and Leader participation.
Gas budget pre-funds possible costs; delivery-versus-payment releases funds after verification.
Leaders stake collateral and face slashing; initial trusted Leaders evolve toward TEEs and permissionless staking.
Use cases: verifiable prediction markets, MEV protection bots, cross-chain portfolios, accountable DAO treasuries.
Limits: verification adds latency, complex multi-agent debugging, incentive misalignment and temporary centralization risks.
Privacy possible via TEEs and ZK-ML; cross-chain proofs reduce custodial bridge reliance.

images.title: Talus's Stack Architecture
images.description: The image is a diagram illustrating Talus's stack architecture, detailing the core components of the Talus Network. The architecture is divided into several layers and components, showcasing the flow of data and operations. At the top, "Agent Applications" interact with "Workflow Triggers" which then connect to "Agent Packages TAP" and "Developer Tools SDK" that feed into the "On-Chain Coordination" layer. The "On-Chain Coordination" layer includes "Workflow Engine" and "Tool Registry" components. The "Workflow Engine" interacts with "Nexus" and "Gas Service" components, while the "Tool Registry" interacts with the "Gas Service". The "Leader Network" layer is connected to the "On-Chain Coordination" layer and includes "Offchain Hub". The "Leader Network" interacts with "Walrus" (Offchain Storage) and the "Tool Execution Layer". The "Tool Execution Layer" includes "ML/AI Models", "Price Oracles", "Gas Service (Privacy)", and "Risk Calculations". The "Tool Execution Layer" sends "Results to Apps" and also provides "Back to Leader Network". The diagram also shows the flow of events, including "Events Emitted", "Monitor Events", "Coordinate Execution", "Execute Tools", "Submit Receipts", and "Store/Retrieve". The diagram also highlights that off-chain compute handles intensive operations. The diagram is a visual representation of the Talus Network's architecture, showing the interaction between on-chain and off-chain components.

images.title: Nexus Architecture and Workflow Diagram
images.description: This diagram illustrates the Nexus architecture and workflow within the Talus stack. The diagram begins with a 'USER' interacting with an 'OFFCHAIN' component. The user's 'REQUESTS' are directed to 'TALUS AGENTS'. The 'TALUS AGENTS' then interact with 'NEXUS ONCHAIN PACKAGES'. There is a two-way interaction between 'TALUS AGENTS' and 'NEXUS ONCHAIN PACKAGES'. 'NEXUS ONCHAIN PACKAGES' also interact with 'ONCHAIN TOOLS' and 'OFFCHAIN TOOLS'. The 'ONCHAIN TOOLS' and 'OFFCHAIN TOOLS' are connected by a line labeled 'TRIGGER TOOLS'. The 'NEXUS ONCHAIN PACKAGES' also interact with another instance of 'NEXUS ONCHAIN PACKAGES' which is connected to the 'OFFCHAIN TOOLS'. The diagram is divided into 'ONCHAIN' and 'OFFCHAIN' sections. The diagram also includes the text 'UPDATE WORKFLOW EXECUTION'. The source of the diagram is 'TALUS'.

content.title: 2026: Infrastructure Re-rating & Demand Shift
content.summary: Infrastructure re-rates; value shifts to apps. Crypto's infrastructure phase is ending as abundant, low-cost blockspace compresses protocol economics. Ethereum scaling produced ~95% fee decline, exposing oversupply and thin protocol fee capture. Blockchains hold >90% market value while capturing <<12% of fees; DeFi captures >70% of fees but accounts for <<10% market cap. Expect a multi-year re-rating: infrastructure multiples fall, user-facing aggregators and apps re-rate up as value migrates to distribution and real-world revenue. Macro positioning and fee volatility increase downside probability near-term.

bullets: Infrastructure built: fast chains, cheap execution, abundant blockspace.
Technical scarcity largely solved; marginal cost of computation collapsed.
Network reliability now resembles commoditized infrastructure, not frontier innovation.
Main problem shifts from building rails to generating recurring demand.
Ethereum scaling drove roughly a 95% decline in fees, enlarging consumer surplus.
Lower costs benefit users but remove pricing power from infrastructure providers.
Open-source replication creates oversupply: many blockchains, too few paying users.
Abundance compresses margins and undermines protocol-level economic leverage.
Current mismatch: Blockchains ≫90% market cap but retain ≪12% of fees.
DeFi captures ≫70% of fees yet represents ≪10% of market capitalization.
Valuation and fee capture should converge; expect infrastructure multiples to decline.
Pair-trade thesis: short infrastructure, long user-facing aggregators and apps.
Real-world adoption (stablecoins, payments rails) reduces frictions but often benefits incumbents.
Value accrues at distribution and offramps, not the rails themselves.
First-mover protocol moats are fragile: liquidity and users are incentive-sensitive.
DEX markets show incumbents can rapidly lose share despite persistent mindshare.
Crypto priced for perfection increases mean-reversion downside probability.
Fee volatility implies revenue is cyclical and levered to macro conditions.
Investable opportunity: crypto-enabled businesses with real revenue and distribution.
Regulatory plumbing (e.g., Fed proposals) and stablecoin adoption are key catalysts.

images.title: Nasdaq Composite and Internet Adoption Growth

content.title: 10 Institutional Crypto Theses for 2026
content.summary: 2026 will be a transition year where blockchains shift from experiment to financial plumbing: financial super apps consolidate distribution and embed tokenized assets; stablecoins pressure bank deposits at the margins; equity tokenization and on‑chain primary raises reach credible pilots; DeFi becomes embedded infrastructure; active crypto ETFs expand productized institutional access; consolidation and M&A accelerate; stablecoins evolve with yield engineering. Adoption advances unevenly across banks, wealth managers, hedge funds, and asset managers, driven by plumbing readiness, regulatory tailwinds (GENIUS Act, SEC shifts), and improved infrastructure.

bullets: All‑in‑one mobile platforms will centralize investing, payments, banking, and wealth tools.
Crypto exchanges, fintechs, and wallets compete to own user distribution and cash flows.
Tokenized assets, prediction markets, stablecoins, and AI tooling become integrated features.
Winning value accrues to front ends and distribution, not isolated products.
Stablecoins achieved product–market fit across payments, payroll, remittances, and SME rails in 2025.
Transactional flows moving on‑chain begin to marginally erode deposits at vulnerable banks.
Regulatory progress (GENIUS Act, clearer issuance models) lowers adoption friction.
Banks must issue, partner, or integrate stablecoins to remain competitive.
Synthetic and real tokenized equity products matured in 2025; Galaxy tokenized SEC‑registered stock.
Expect pilots of tokenized shares, DEX secondary venues, and SEC custody/recordkeeping pathways in 2026.
On‑chain primary raises (ICO 2.0 / Direct Issuance) will run as dual‑track experiments.
Tokenization enables 24/7 markets, automated compliance, and composability with DeFi.
DeFi increasingly runs 'in the back' for CeFi front ends (embedded lending, liquidity, pricing).
Protocols like Morpho and Aave show institutional integrations and significant collateral flows.
Abstracted DeFi shifts differentiation to user experience, distribution, and trust.
Successful protocols begin to generate recurring revenue via embedded services.
Consolidation accelerates as firms M&A to build super app stacks; Coinbase led 2025 activity.
Active crypto ETFs emerge as a fast‑growing institutional wrapper beyond passive spot products.
Managers will offer volatility‑managed, income, and tactical crypto ETF strategies.
Tokenized funds, DATs, and structured products broaden institutional access.

content.title: 25 Charts That Defined 2025
content.summary: Liquidity, structure, and adoption defined 2025. Global crypto cap moved through three phases: ~30% Q1 decline, summer rebound to ~$4.3T ATH, then a ~36% correction after a $20B+ October liquidation. Implied BTC volatility trended lower except the October spike. Stablecoin supply hit ~$300B and stablecoin transfers exceeded Visa+PayPal+remittances combined (>2x). Base showed outsized stablecoin velocity. Tokens minted accelerated, memecoin hype (TRUMP on Solana) briefly dominated Q1, then attention shifted to fundamentals. On-chain futures, bridges (USDT0 >$50B transfers), RWA value ($18.5B), vaults ($7B peak), and Hyperliquid builder revenue ($400k/day) signalled product-market fit across derivatives, RWAs, and composable DeFi.

bullets: Three distinct market phases: ~30% Q1 decline, rebound to ~$4.3T, then ~36% October correction.
Global net liquidity led market moves; October $20B+ liquidation drove divergence and reduced market-maker liquidity.
NASDAQ and crypto followed global liquidity trends with an 11-week lead correlation.
Deribit BTC implied volatility declined through most of 2025 with an October spike around the liquidation event.
On-chain futures volume rose versus CEXs, marking clear product-market-fit for perpetuals and composability.
Spot exchange volumes and on-chain yield (SUSDE APR) compressed over the year after mid-year peaks.
Total on-chain stablecoin supply reached ~$300B, driven by trading, DeFi, and institutional use.
Stablecoin transfer volume surpassed Visa, PayPal, and remittances combined for the first time, ending 2025 >2x.
Base exhibited much higher stablecoin velocity, boosted by Coinbase integrations and merchant activity.
Token minting accelerated via standards (e.g., ERC-1155) and mint-focused socialFi platforms.
TRUMP memecoin (launched Jan 17 on Solana) delivered massive early volume and multi-billion market cap, marking Q1 local top.
Memecoin share on Solana DEXes declined later in 2025 as beta and fundamental assets regained attention.
Active loans rose ~60% while average valuations fell >45%, creating valuation fundamentals divergence.
Revenue vs. valuations showed a >400% spread for select fundamental protocols.
On-chain RWAs tripled to $18.5B; tokenized institutional funds (e.g., BlackRock BUIDL) and private credit drove growth.

images.title: Monthly Spot Exchange Volume vs. SUSDE APR (%) in 2025
images.description: This chart illustrates the monthly spot exchange volume in relation to SUSDE APR (%) for the year 2025. The x-axis represents the months from December 2024 to December 2025. The left y-axis displays the spot volume in US dollars, ranging from $0.0T to $3.5T. The right y-axis indicates the SUSDE APR (%), ranging from 0% to 30%. The chart features two data series: a purple bar chart representing the spot volume for each month and a black line graph showing the SUSDE APR (%). The spot volume peaks in December 2024 at approximately $2.8T and declines sharply to around $1.0T by March 2025, then fluctuates between $1.0T and $2.0T for the rest of the year. The SUSDE APR (%) starts at around 25% in December 2024, decreases to about 5% by June 2025, and then oscillates between 4% and 6% for the remainder of the year. The source of the data is Re7, Blockworks, and DeFi Llama.

content.title: Bittensor TAO: flow-based emissions & sentiment
content.summary: Flow-based emissions replaced price-based emissions on Bittensor in November 2025: TAO emissions to subnets now track net TAO inflows rather than alpha prices. Community sentiment across 49,799 X and Reddit posts in November stayed positive (median ~0.078, mean ~0.1045) despite falling volume. Narrative highlights: predicted large capital inflows, DeFi integrations (USDC <> dTAO swaps, TaoFi, wallet partnerships), merit-based rewards favoring subnets with real TAO purchases, MEV front-running concerns, fragmentation debates, and calls to deregister underperforming subnets. Data shows 66.7% positive posts, stable 5-day rolling median ~0.08, and active developer/infra improvements driving optimistic outlook.

bullets: November 2025 upgrade shifts emissions from price-based to flow-based calculation.
TAO emissions now allocated by net TAO inflow to subnets rather than alpha token price.
Subnets with net positive TAO flow receive more emissions; net outflow can yield 0% emissions.
Community expects sizeable capital inflows into TAO and dTAO; liquidity bridges and swaps emphasized.
TaoFi, USDC bridges, and Talisman wallet integration framed as catalysts for TAO liquidity.
Discussions forecast rotation of capital into mid-cap AI narratives once resistances break.
Flow model rewards subnets that generate real TAO purchases and on-chain growth.
Merit-based emissions favor miners/validators/stakers providing strong signal; buybacks must align.
Model described as increasing Darwinian competition among subnets for genuine capital.
49,799 cleaned posts from X and Reddit (Nov 1–28) analyzed with enhanced lexicon sentiment model.
66.7% positive, 10.1% negative, 23.2% neutral; median overall sentiment ~0.0775, mean ~0.1045.
Daily volume fell from ~1,300 to ~300–500 posts; 5-day rolling median stayed ~0.08 with narrow variance.
MEV/front-running during alpha buybacks is primary negative driver, creating real financial loss.
Cultural shift and fragmentation: criticism that dTAO increased individualism and speculative behavior.
Calls to deregister underperforming subnets; debates over 'dead weight' projects and bad actors.

Reddit had 1,012 posts with a mean sentiment of 0.0854 and a median sentiment of 0.0591.

content.title: 2025 Open Models: Year in Review
content.summary: Open models made a major leap in 2025: DeepSeek R1, Qwen 3, and Kimi K2 led a year where open releases rivaled closed models on benchmarks and broadened adoption. DeepSeek R1 (MIT license) pushed Chinese labs to open-license; Qwen 3 became the most-downloaded base and a go-to academic/fine-tune choice; Kimi K2 impressed with performance and style. Runner-ups include MiniMax M2, GLM-4.5, GPT-OSS, Gemma 3, and Olmo 3. Honorable mentions: Parakeet 3, Nemotron 2, Moondream 3, Granite 4, SmolLM3. Tier list ranks Frontier labs, noteworthy contributors, specialists, and rising orgs. Predictions: open-model deployments scale further in 2026, though closed models keep advantages in robustness and real-world richness.

bullets: 2025 marked a turning point: open models rival closed models on many benchmarks.
Open releases broadened beyond niche use-cases into mainstream deployment possibilities.
Closed models still lead in robustness and real-world behavior despite benchmark parity.
DeepSeek R1 — released Jan 20, MIT license; catalyzed Chinese labs to open-license releases.
Qwen 3 — multi-form family (dense, MoE, vision, embeddings); top in downloads and fine-tuning.
Kimi K2 — Moonshot AI’s focused line; strong performance and distinctive style.
MiniMax M2 — large step-up from M1; high sustained usage via Chinese release playbook.
GLM-4.5 — Zhipu’s breakthrough with smaller Air variant and wider attention.
GPT-OSS — OpenAI’s open release, excels in agentic apps but weaker in world knowledge and multilinguality.
Parakeet 3 — best-in-class speech-to-text with low-latency on-device performance and broad language coverage.
Nemotron 2 — NVIDIA’s mamba2-transformer hybrids, many datasets released openly.
Moondream 3, Granite 4, SmolLM3 — strong vision, reasoning toggles, and on-device small-model options.
Tier list: Frontier (DeepSeek, Qwen, Moonshot), Close competitors (Zhipu, Minimax), Noteworthy (Tencent, IBM, NVIDIA, Google, Mistral), Specialists and On-the-rise groups.
Monthly HF uploads ~30k–60k models; Interconnects curates ~600 models yearly for Artifacts.
Prediction: 2026 sees wider open-model deployments; closed models keep advantages in robustness and real-world usage.

The Frontier tier includes logos for Whale, 0x0, and a piano key design. The Close Competitors tier features logos for Z, MINIMAX. The Noteworthy tier includes logos for a stylized F, a silhouette of a person, and a green M logo. The Specialists tier includes logos for a stylized hexagon, a plus sign, a smiling moon, a series of diagonal lines, a cartoon family, a smiling face with hands, a flame, a grid of squares, Xiaomi MiMo, and a network of blue dots. The On the Rise tier includes logos for a bar graph, a plus sign, a brick wall, a paw print, a sailboat, a cartoon character, a CV logo, and a stylized arrow. The Honorable Mentions tier includes logos for a stylized infinity symbol, a Chinese character logo, a star, and a green network of dots.

content.title: PRIME: Figure's On‑chain HELOC Yield on Kamino
content.summary: PRIME tokenizes $19B of Figure HELOCs. PRIME provides an on‑chain, yield-bearing asset backed by Figure’s HELOC portfolio targeting prime borrowers (avg FICO 745, ~62.3% LTV). Market cap reached $73.76M and base APY is 8%. Kamino integration attracted $108.72M in deposits in two weeks, driven by native yield and Multiply leverage (avg 5.66x). USDC loop net yields ranged ~11.3%–21.0%; CASH loop ~9.9%–15.5%. PRIME can be bought with USDC on Kamino or minted via wYSDL on Hastra, offering institutional-style short-term warehouse financing on-chain.

bullets: PRIME backed by over $19 billion in Figure’s on‑chain HELOC collateral.
Average borrower FICO ~745 and portfolio LTV ~62.32%, prioritizing prime credit.
Market cap $73.76M; base APY advertised at 8.00%.
$108.72M deposited on Kamino within two weeks of launch.
PRIME functions as a short‑term liquidity layer (warehouse replacement) for HELOC originators.
Capital lent to regulated originators, collateralized by homogenized HELOC pools with liquidation legal recourse.
Loans are bundled and sold into securitizations roughly every 40–45 days, repaying warehouse advances.
Yield derives from borrower interest; PRIME exposure targets early‑stage loan performance.
Dedicated isolated PRIME market on Kamino enabled rapid supply lock and leveraged strategies.
Multiply product dominates liquidity (≈94.24% of available liquidity), average leverage 5.66x.
USDC debt loop yields ~11.30%–21.01%; CASH loop yields ~9.89%–15.45%, net returns timing sensitive.
Supply APYs stabilized ~4.8%–5.6%; borrow rates ~5.5%–7%; utilization caps reached on both stablecoins.
Shows institutional credit can be composable and liquid on DeFi rails when end‑to‑end managed.
Rapid adoption may attract capital but exposes on‑chain lenders to securitization and rate risks.
Net returns highly sensitive to borrowing costs and debt-token selection; timing risk for levered positions.
PRIME provides a potential blueprint for future RWA integrations and institutional onboarding.
